description:
Love Yee's!!! Reminds me of the old school Chinese restaurants we frequented as kids.  Where you go for the food and not necessarily the ambiance or service.  And the food here is really good.  We stop in every time we are in SF usually more than once.
Must haves:
Anything from the deli case.  Best roast duck in SF.
Roast duck wonton mein.  
Tofu-seafood hotpot.  
Salt-pepper chicken wings.
Anything off their 3 items for $23 menu.  (I love this price).

A must visit if you're in SF Chinatown.
author: Iakona C.

description: My partner and I were walking in the neighborhood around 1am and we peered inside the restaurant to see a cat walking all over the cutting boards and counters. Would definitely be cautious if choosing to dine there
author: Margaux Q.

description: I've been coming to this restaurant since I was a kid but I think they've changed ownership a couple time through the years. On this day I came in for just something specific, Jook. That's rice porridge. I brought my girlfriend who is Hispanic and had never had rice porridge. She wanted to try it out and I took her here. I ended up not regretting that decision because we ordered the Jook with cod and it was fantastic. The fish was perfect and the rice and soup mixture was dead on. The thing that stand out is that the soup didn't taste like they used anything to make the porridge think. See some places will use gelatin to thicken up the porridge but not here. I also ordered a Singapore rice noodle, this is one of my favorite dishes to order when I go place and it was fantastic. Tons of shrimp and chashu in it. The price is one of the cheapest in the neighborhood (see my review for Yuet Lee). My girlfriend now is a fan of Jook and a fan of Yee's. So give this place a chance.
author: Patrick T.

description: Food was nothing exceptional. We ordered the roast pork over rice and wonton noodle. 2 plates shared between 3 people. It filled us up. But the charged us $2 for sharing!!!! The service was poor, as they were rude to us. And the wonton noodle soup tasted plain. Soup base has no flavor, it was like sipping water. The wonton was basically just plain meat wrapped in wonton.
author: Uyen N.

description:
Very fresh duck in the delicious soup...The vegetables over rice was very nice too.
I have never eaten in Chinatown, and this was a great 1st time ezperience
author: Les G.

description: This place is the place to go for authentic Chinese food. Don't expect it to taste like Panda Express. This is an authentic Guangdong style restaurant and serves authentic Guangdong style food. Typical of most Chinese restaurants, this place is noisy, which might be unsettling to tourists. The servers are nothing but nice to me, but they may come off as ride because of language barriers between them and their guests. They don't speak fluent English, since they are immigrants, so give them a break!
author: Kelli T.

description: Finally have roast goose in USA！The taste of it is average. Roast duck and soy chicken is good！Worth trying it！Staffs are nice and cash only.
author: Viki C.

description:
Not only was the food good at this place, but it was a unique experience as well. I was drawn in by the ducks in the window. I saw them and had to try it. When I went I was by myself. I was seated at a big table with other lone diners. That made it fun. They brought me very hot, perfect tea. I had a bowl of wonton soup that was hot and delicious. I also had the duck rice plate. It was huge and tasted good too. The rice plates are very reasonably priced, especially for the mountain of food they are. It was fun to sit with the locals and see what everyone was getting.
There was a counter where you could order all kinds of roasted meats and unique items. There were also tanks at the back with big live fish and turtles. 
I felt like I really found a local jewel in this place.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Authentic Chinese/Cantonese cuisine. Large portions, great deals and clean establishment. I absolutely love their three dishes for $20 special. I ordered the following and it was more than enough to feed four adults. The meal also comes with a complimentary soup as well. 

Fried chicken: plump chicken, crispy skin and very moist. 

Black bean clams: clams galore! More clams than the actual shells. Oh my! 

Fried flounder: crispy deliciousness paired with an amazing sauce. Mix that sauce with white rice and you are set.

CASH ONLY
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I'm laughing all the way to the BANK thanks to Yee's. 

Yee's is where you can find authentic Chinese/Cantonese food that won't burn a hole in your wallet. No need to waste time looking for any other Chinese/Cantonese cuisine restaurant in Chinatown; just come to Yee's. 

Must try: 
Salt and Pepper Pork Chop
Roast Duck Won Ton Soup

They're also very generous with the portions and I almost always have leftovers for another meal. 

Cash only - you guessed it.
author: Sam K.

description: We stumbled upon Yee's and we were so happy we did! The food was amazing and authentically Chinese! The prices were perfect! Thank you!! We will be back!!
author: Mrs. Diane C.

description: Been here twice now and has not disappointed!  Love the roast goose! Wish we could get this dish in LA or OC!
author: James T.

description: In the Chinatown area, this is my go to spot for barbecued meat. I've eaten in and done takeout a number of times. If it's your first time at the restaurant & you don't know what to order, go for the barbecued meat section of the menu. The barbecued pork (char siu), roast pork, & duck are all delicious. It's pretty packed during lunch time but the food comes out quickly. Cash only.
author: Ruby C.

description:
Love the 23 menu, you choose 3 dishes and included house soup of the day.
Definitely stopping by again.
author: Maria H.

description: Huge disappointment. After reading reviews and seeing this place serves goose I came here to try it out. Had the goose and rice plate and got about 10 pieces of goose. Decent amount of meat until I picked it up. Mostly bones and it was super gamey. I love having sauce on my rice, but I wasnt able to eat the rice that had sauce it in. The goose was tough and hard to pull off whatever meat it had. The complimentary soup that came was good.
author: Henry T.

description: The only place I SF we go to for Chinese food until today...just finished a nice lunch with my husband, paid for our meal, started gathering our things and were discussing how much of a tip to leave on the table when we were approached by a waiter telling us the bill did not include the tip and that we needed to give him $3.00, less than we anticipated leaving.. he was rude and loud and didn't give us a chance to make the decision ourselves.. well guess what??? You're gonna get loud and tell me what I HAVE to do? We walked out all the while he was  getting louder.. as far as I know tipping is OPTIONAL mr!  If you had kept your mouth shut you would have had your tip.
author: Monica S.

description:
TL;DR - Do you like a serving of second hand smoke while you eat? If so, this could be the place for you.

I know chinese restaurants are not known for amazing service or gourmet quality food... but this place kinda lacked everything. 

The food was overly salty. The service was abysmal. The inside felt sticky and gross. 

But the biggest kicker was the fact that if you're sitting inside, you can breathe in that amazing second hand smoke from the 10 or so old asian guys smoking outside. 

Pass. Hard pass.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Eating here after a golf practice on Sunday, 
I ordered a wonton soup and beef, brocolis noodles. The soup was not bad but not more to say. The noodles are crispy as I wanted, beef is tender but they don't give me broccolis but long vegetables not cut ! Sauce is just an usual Chinese sauce.
For me this restaurant was the souvenir to be glad to see in front of my table, a family with 3 children giving hands for blessing their meal. Yeah, for me it's the first time to see this and not watching this on TV ! Children - 2 years old, ten years old - were quiet, not disturbing a lot the restaurant.
author: Marie-Claire L.

description: Had the standard BBQ combo plate with duck and BBQ pork. Price was fair. Flavors were legit. Portion was fine, although could have had more meat and less rice. Overall, not shabby.
author: Yu Z.

description: We parked in Chinatown after visiting the Mammal Center and Bonita lighthouse.  The traffic was crazy but we found a spot in front of Yee's Restaurant.  We first walked up and down Grant Street but then decided that this was the best option.  My dad and mom did the ordering for us and we made some good choices of seafood hot pot as well as beef and chinese broccoli.  Price was very reasonable and food was hot at our table.  Overall, we were happy with our choices but the traffic can be tough to beat for prime parking spot.
author: Phillip Y.

description: Having BBQ goose here is the main reason to come to SF from LA! I love it! It's the taste from my home town! The servers are very nice, too!
author: Jamie T.

description:
Typical chaotic Cantonese BBQ restaurant. I actually enjoyed my food here. Best thing I had was the wonton noodle soup. The noodles weren't the best quality, but it was passable.

My dad (decades of cooking experience) thinks some of the flavors were a little off, but nothing egregious. Stir-fried clams were a deal, but they were loaded with sand. Roast duck was okay. 

Service was about what you'd expect, but there's still a method to the madness.
author: Warren C.

description:
Service - 3 stars.  Quick and efficient but not rude

Food - 4 stars. Authentic Cantonese staples. We ordered the pork and preserved egg porridge, wonton and char sui noodles, and a double roasted meat platter. We are pleased with the generous portion size.  The tea is meh but you don't come to a place like this for its tea.

Cleanliness - 3 stars. Clean enough but floor feels grease and bathroom is less desirable.
author: PK L.

description:
Our lunch looked like pig glop and didn't taste much better.

Normally when I got out with my pal at PG&E, we go to Broadway Dim Sum.  But they were doing remodeling and were in hurry as my pal had a 1 PM meeting.  We walked down Grant Street and came across Yee's.

We were seated right away by a man who looked like a manager type.  We ordered the 2 lunch specials ($9.25).  That was our mistake as we didn't try any of the bbq items or what the Chinese contractors around us were eating.  The plate consisted of sweet and sour pork, a fried chicken leg, fried rice, chow mein, and some non-descript vegetables which may be Napa cabbage.  The order came quickly, but the presentation was poor.  I've worked in many restaurants when I was younger as a dishwasher and scrapped many plates of food into the garbage.  Our meal looked like it was scooped out of the trash can.  

We asked our waiter/manager twice for the bill, but he took his time.  When I have him a $20 bill for the tab, he never returned with the change.  I suppose he thought he would keep it.  Since the $1.50 change wasn't that much we left additional monies for a tip.  But then again, we thought they were presumptuous and took back our monies and left the place.

With a health score of 68, the poor presentation and service, and so-so taste, it is unlikely that we will return here.
author: Robert J.

description: I wouldn't consider this a tourist destination nor a place to bring new friends. The only thing you'll impress them with is the authentic  cooking geared towards locals with light wallets. If it's not on the menu they can make anything you want. It's noisy and service can be abrupt and or nonexistent at times. Face it, it's a local dive and it wears the moniker proudly, they're not trying to impress anyone. It's good food for a good price, and they do it well.
author: Gary W.

description: Price is reasonable and food is good. We ordered the special 3 dishes and soup of the day for $20.99 back in summer last year when we visited SF. We also ordered yellow watermelon juice which was very refreshing.  We went back again another day too.
author: Mary W.

description: Ok, so I'm not really into Chinese food because most of it is Americanized and expensive. This place surprised me, it was very authentic tasting and good prices. I wish we had more Chinese restaurants like this. I guess if we are craving Chinese we'll just have to go an hour to China Town. Nothing near home can compete.
author: Buenafe S.

description: Terrible. Food was plain. Service was rude. The restaurant was dirty. I would not recommend.bad
author: Kc N.

description:
Solid Cantonese joint in Chinatown that does 3 big entrees for $22. None of their bbq items are on there though.  We've only gone for lunch time, so I'm not sure if the deal works for dinner. It's served with a big bowl of plain chicken or pork bone soup and rice. I usually go with 2 of my other coworkers and we each choose a dish. The entrees aren't your small lunch special plates, they're giant heaping plates of whatever you're ordering, so worth it! 

Our favorites:

Seafood and tofu clay plot
Salt and pepper spare ribs

Definitely one of the grungy Chinese places in Chinatown, but such a great deal!  Cash only.
author: Linda H.

description: I normally often go in here with my family before and we do really like the food in here, however, since I got busy, I barely come in here to hang out with my family. The instance happened to me was the staff was so arrogant and he even trynna' raise his voice towards me just because I dont get what he was saying at first. Then when we done with our order, he went to the kitchen and seems like he was talking shit about me/us because when he started talking to his co-workers, they all looked at us.
author: Nicole L.

description: Chow mien Noodles have a really nice smoky flavor. They are thinner similar to the wonton noodles. Came in as one and sat at a table with no condiments or chopsticks. They just gave a fork and a napkin. They also serve a complimentary hot tea. Portion is pretty big. Around 8pm now and there is no bbq item available :(
author: Stacey T.

description:
I've been coming here since 2010 and it's hit or miss.

The consistent things to get are the barbqued duck, and white chicken bak cheet guy with ginger and scallion sauce

The chow mein and chow fun are good here portions are huge

Sweet and sour ribs are consistent
Fish filet with tender greens are good here
Curry chow fun without bell peppers is also good here.

They do off the menu items to if you call them ahead of time .

I was here once and had a chicken and black bean sauce rice dish and the chicken tasted weird other than that experience it's been consistent . This place has large portions and is fairly priced !!
author: DOM d.

description:
Came in with the fam after shopping around Chinatown last week. There's no greeting or sitting us down so we gotta find an empty table ourselves. Food was okay ain't that all great. 

I only saw 2 or maybe 3 servers. There isn't a particular server than covers certain tables so you gotta hunt one down/get their attention. So all in all service ain't all that great. Then we asked for our bill. 

So one would assume it's normal to expect crappy tip (or lack thereof) for crappy service. I am NOT joking when the lady handed our bill (still on her hands), stood there waiting WHILE we count our money!!!! Who does that $hit unless the customer wants you to wait there (place is cash only ugh).

Service is already crappy yet she has the decency to ask for more tips??!! Listen, I'll gladly give you a tip (of advice): TIPS ARE OPTIONAL NOT MANDATORY!!!!! You're lucky that we even tip at all!  That made me so argh! Ugh seriously?! I should've took back the tips instead!

I would rather have personally tipped the guy server with classes who somewhat seated us and prompt service instead of her.

Btw, the deli workers don't wash their hands after handling money. Bad hygiene and def unsanitary! Bleh! And make sure to double check your itemized bill because the way I saw ours really looks illegible. Double check it!
 
Fellow Yelpers, you are warned of this bad greedy practice and my experience with that waitress!!!
author: Cindy L.

description:
A lot of food for the money on the main tourist street in Chinatown, but by Broadway, not near the curio shops.

This place gets crowded but the food is mediocre. Many dishes are salty, without enough seasoning.  Very popular with people from Asia.

Chinese barbecue and deep fried foods are the strong suits.

Good place for college aged men who like large portions for low prices.
author: Joanna S.

description: Overall this place was interesting. Your usual Chinese dine in or take out type of restaurant where you go seat yourself and the waiter comes moments later. The food was bounce passed to the table and it arrived fast. I ordered the two types of meats (Roasted Pork and duck) over rice and cabbage and it was pretty good. The pork has a good ratio of meat, fat and that super crispy skin! The duck was good but not as much meat and kind of dry. Both of the meat portions were given a decent amount. I would most likely come back again!
author: Devin T.

description:
Perfectly average but decent Cantonese food along the main road in Chinatown. I was overwhelmed by just how many restaurants there were to choose from in SF Chinatown, but I decided on this one because of the tempting barbecued and roast meats hanging in the front window, the decent reviews, and the really cheap prices. We were quickly shown a seat inside and eventually caught the eye of someone who would take our order. Service is definitely not their strong point, but I wasn't expecting much for a Chinatown restaurant to start with, so eh. 

My boyfriend and I split a two-meat combo plate of barbecued pork and roast duck, as well as the pan-fried noodles with seafood. I grew up eating pan-fried noodles with seafood at my favorite local Chinese restaurant, so this brought back fond memories, though I have to admit the fried noodles in their rendition were on the greasy side and the seafood sauce on top was pretty bland. My boyfriend didn't like it at all, but it was also his first time having this particular dish. We were satisfied with the amount of seafood in it though, and all of it was cooked well. The barbecued pork and roast duck were both delicious but very fatty compared to what I'm used to. Also, some pieces that had been sitting on the bottom in the salty greasy sauce they poured on top ended up being too salty, and by the end of our meal, it was just too much.  

All in all, I think we paid something like $15 total for our meal, not including tax + tip (can't remember anymore). Really cheap considering these were two plates full of food, and we had plenty of leftovers to take home. If you have more people, the 3 dishes for $20 deal is a real steal, but the menu for that doesn't include any bbq/roast meats, and that was what I was really there for. The inside is your typical Chinatown dump, but it seemed clean enough. The health score of 65 is a little concerning, but I didn't get sick from eating here, so I guess I won that game of Russian roulette. This place got packed around dinner-time, so it seems to be popular with the locals. It's nothing to travel out of your way for, but if you're hungry and want a quick, cheap, decent meal, this isn't a bad choice.
author: Katie H.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: 

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: 

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

3/3 Stars: 

_____

Overall Experience

5/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words
Great place to eat in or take out
author: Elliott N.

description:
Stumbled in here on a rainy day and sat down at a communal table for a quick bite.  I ordered the lunch combo and it was alright, nothing to write home about. But upon finishing, I noticed that their health card was posted right next to me. According to the health dept. they scored an 83 out of 100 and so far I am not sick. Stay tuned folks

Update:  I did not get sick!
author: Ricardo S.

description:
We were brought to this restaurant by an elderly gentleman that insisted this was authentic Chinese food.  He said to notice the Chinese eating at the restaurant, and that is how you would know it was authentic Chinese.  It was packed with a lot of Chinese people.  We just weren't that impressed with the food.

 We ordered the Kung Pao chicken, sweet and sour chicken, noodles, shrimp with veggies, and some sliced pork.  Tea was brought to the table right away which was great.  The best things we ordered were the sweet and sour chicken and Kung Pao chicken.  The noodles were horrible.  They were super rubbery and hard to eat.

The food was brought super fast and the waitress was very friendly.  The prices were very cheap, but the food wasn't anything to write home about.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Like others have said, VERY authentic Cantonese restaurant!! It's loud, crowded, tables and chairs are plain/basic, lacks "Western" customer service, you order & get your meal FAST (they want you IN and OUT fast!), there's meat hanging at the window, bathrooms are at the back so you have to walk through kitchen where they wash, all space is used up... AUTHENTIC!! Chinese people do not put effort into ambiance, customer service, and stuff Westerner's care about; and that's what makes it absolutely amazing!

Food is fantastic!!! If you want truly yummy Chinese food, not overpriced "Westernized Chinese" food, and generous portions, come here. Their prices are also appropriately set, you won't go broke after a well proportioned meal. [Tip: get the 3 dishes for a set price (I forget the price, around $23) it's the best deal]

Give this place a try, don't be shy!! As a take home, get their Sticky Rice Dumplings for $2-3, amazing breakfast!!!
author: Carmen L.

description:
I used to come here ALL THE TIME with my god-grandma and family. Food was tasty and super cheap. A lot of favs under the 3 for $20 menu including salted fish eggplant claypot. YUM. My mom ordered a small roast pig from here for my wedding reception. It was really good. The meat was flavorful unlike much roast pig where the skin is good but the meat is bland. 

The roast pig and 1-2 entrees that supplemented the other food at the reception fed 120 people for $200. The other bbq/roasted items are good. We always took home a few zhong (sticky rice in banana leaf) for the week. 

It's a Chinese restaurant so it's great for large groups and causing a ruckus. The English menu is the same as the Chinese menu, however they have more offerings in Chinese.

Come here if you can navigate a dirty cheapo Chinese restaurant that belongs on Stockton, not on Grant. I've seen many non-Chinese people come through here and happily gorge.
author: Rena J.

description:
The food is authentic and delicious. Go with an appetite! My friend and I left with extremely full stomachs for under $20. 
You can go ahead and sit yourself. There is a cooler for drinks against the wall. Feel free to help yourself to drinks; you don't have to wait for a waiter to bring it to you. They do provide complimentary hot tea -which is also delicious: and free sliced oranges for dessert. 
I ordered beef wonton noodle soup-so good. I left stuffed and I couldn't even finish it; and I made it a point to go with hunger. The broth was also delicious which I think was the star of the meal that gave everything flavor. 
It is spacious and can accommodate parties of 6 as well.
author: Ara N.

description:
Very authentic Hong Kong style Cantonese food and service - Efficient, taste good and make you full at a very reasonable price.
Their barbecued meat is tasty and not greesy (I tried duck and soy sauce chicken). Generous portion for dishes.
To my surprise, there are complimentary soup and orange. The soup itself will not be very impressive, but it is a very traditional practice in HK style Cantonese BBQ restaurant. These two already worth my tips!
The restaurant is quite busy so it would be good to eat quick and return the table. If you would like to have a good seating and good service, it would not be an ideal place for you. If you are looking for a quick eat and authentic Cantonese food, here would be a good choice.
For hygienic concerns, I don't see a problem. The restroom is acceptably clean, no incensts were seen and I didn't feel unwell after eating.
author: Shirley K.

description:
Nothing extraordinary about this place, but it's a decent bang for your buck.

We ordered 3 entrees & received a complimentary large bowl of soup. Mostly liquid/ broth, but eh, it was complimentary. 

Like most Chinese restaurants, you'll have to ask repeatedly for more water, tea, utensils etc. The service is average. We came around lunch time, so it was packed & expectedly noisy. 

I also ordered a bunch of stuff to go. I asked for "Garlic crab" & the wait took about 20-25 minutes. I double checked the box, and found a crab over rice, with a bunch of curry. It turns out that they thought I said "'Gālí' crab"......which means "curry" in Chinese. Language / enunciation fail. 

So, I guess it would be helpful to have someone who knows how to speak Chinese with you.
author: Melissa J.

description: Not much I could talk about this place since I came here for an umpteenth time with my family.  Just one of the very useful Chinese restaurants for lunchtime.  There are times when I start having lunch with my wife at 3pm.  I used to like fried calamari; that's one of my favorite appetizers.
author: Jimmy C.

description: One of the best restaurants in Chinatown. The servers/owners are soooo friendly and make the best food for a really good price. Don't go to any bougie restaurants downtown when you could find a place like this where the meal plates are $9.
author: Calvin H.

description: We have been to this place twice. Why? It's hidden in Chinatown and you come across it when you least expect it. The first time we were here was when it was the four of us. My dad, my brother when he was just a child, my mom and I. It's been nearly 20 years and we made a return. Unfortunately my dad is not around to enjoy the wondeful cuisine provided by this place. He's with God. God Bless. So in honor of him, I do this review. I would recommend this place for anyone looking to eat some quality Chinese food. It was our last day in S.F. and what to eat for dinner. Well, how about the place we dined here almost 20 years ago. Well, we came here by chance. We were strolling through chinatown and came across here. This is where we dined during our last night in S.F. on 2nd of Jan, 2017. Just come by and order the 3 dishes for  XX amount of dollars. They have the promotion where you order 3 dishes, you pay a certain price. of course we were hungry so we ordered 6 dishes. Soup is complimentary. We ate the Seafood tofu pot, Fish with bok choy, and some other dishes. The food is great. It's not your 5 star type restaurant, but it's definitely a family restaurant. The prices of the food is cheap, but the taste of the food is definitely good. During the day, there's a line outside waiting to get the BBQ food. They must be doing something right.
author: Arthur W.

description:
great deal on the take away - choose 3 dishes for $6.5 and 4 dishes for $8. afternoon special -
 3 dishes for $6.
we bought 4 dishes for $8 - lotus root vege, lo-duck, BBQ pork and crispy roasted pork. All tasted great and reasonably bg portion ! will surely come back again.
author: Joyce T.

description:
Don't be frightened by the roast duck and bbq pork hanging in the window.  My first time here I watched a group of tourist pointing towards the duck hanging in the window before scurrying off into the night.

This visit I tried the yang chow fried rice.  The bbq pork was very good but this dish was too salty and not very good.  I also had the zongzi/Chinese tamale.  It was not very good as there were too many peanuts and that was the main flavor to the dish.

From another visit:
I ordered half a roast duck for $8 and bbq pork pan fried noodles for $6.  The roast duck was awesome!  Nice crispy skin with awesome flavor.  The meat was tender and delicious.  This is one of the best plates of roast duck I have ever had!  The pan fried noodles were very good.  This dish is similar to bbq pork chow mein dry style from Hong Kong bbq.

From a previous trip:
I tried the 3 dishes for $18 deal.  I picked mongolian beef, peking spareribs, and the salt and pepper wings.  The mongolian beef was tender, had good flavor, and a little kick to it.  The peking spareribs had a nice crust and tasty sauce drizzled on them.  This was my fav dish of the three.  The salt and pepper wings tasted like they may have been marinated in soy sauce before frying.  Very tasty.  This was alot of food with the addition of white rice and more than we could finish.  The only disappointing thing here is the tea.  I'm really picky about tea and I'm willing to pay for good loose leaf tea.  This tea was a real generic prebewed stuff that was sitting around in a warmer.

Overall the bbq meats are awesome here but the other dishes are a bit off.  This place has great bang for the buck but you will find more refined non bbq meat dishes at places like Great Eastern.
author: Soo H.

description:
An ok chinese bbq shop in c-town

Visitors to c-town will likely have walked by this place at least once or twice. The prominent location means that I've walked past this place numerous times, but this is the first time I went in. I ordered the main dish (bbq pork with rice), and the portions are Huge! One dish of rice can last me 2 meals, and as expected the price is very reasonable.

In terms of decor, the inside is definitely not one of the nicest, but it does look like the place has seen its fair share of history and stood the test of time.

Overall, a not bad place to visit for chinese bbq.
author: Henry L.

description: After an adventurous day of walking all over Chinatown my fiancé wanted a whole duck from somewhere that had them in the window. We walked in and were seated right away. We ordered the whole duck, combination fried rice, combination chow mien, and Kung pao chicken. When we ordered the server recommended that we move to a bigger table because it was going to be a lot of food and it was! All the food was good but the duck and the chow mien were AMAZING. And even better the bill was less then $50! We ate so much food and still had leftovers for 2 days. This place is awesome and we will definitely be back next time we're in Chinatown.
author: Amanda M.

description: we have been here twice with some friends for dinner it is pretty good and they give you a good amount .they have specials 3 plates for $25 I think .on a set menu. but they do have other items also.I use to come here for the sweet & sour pork and afternoon specials which was good too. i'm sure we will be back.
author: Nellie J.

description: This place is good for a home cooked Cantonese meal. We had the tofu chicken /salty fish, bock Choy w/cod fillet & seafood tofu dish.
author: Rowland W.

description:
We were told to visit this place prior to visiting Chinatown in San Fran.  I suppose Yee's has been around for quite sometimes and the older generation seems to know a lot about them.  There is even a counterfeit restaurant with similar Chinese name around the corner on Broadway St.

One of their specialties here was the so-called Cantonese Roast Goose, and they were probably the only place that served them around here.  However, our traveling companion who is also a Chinese BBQ expert informed us that the goose was really a larger breed of duck with the beak trimmed off, and then they jacked up the price to like $20ish each, while duck was have sold for half as much.  Not off to a good start.

Regardless, we tried some of their dishes.  The house veggie was ok.  Char Siu was a bit disappointing with an amateur usage of all part of the pig, but flavor was ok. House Noodles looked like a big mess, but it tasted ok though.  Their Roasted Duck was decent with crisp skin.  Soy Chicken was good as well.  We got the Sturgeon Deluxe, which came in a stir-fried dish and another cooked in soup.  The fish was a bit small though and the soup was not very good.

I really want to like these traditional old town Chinese joint, they definitely has a lot of rich culture touch to them.  However, when they got questionable business practices and integrity like selling ducks pretending to be goose, it really got me thinking about the rest of things they sell.
author: Tony L.

description: This restaurant is rated the worst ever for me, worst service, worst food and cashier asked for tips when handed me the changes
author: Harley D.

description:
One of the best Chinese food restaurants in Chinatown. The thing with this area is you gotta weed out the restaurants that are just purely attracting tourists and the ones that have genuine good authentic Chinese food 

This is good authentic Chinese food served "dirty and plentiful yet delicious" if you know what I mean

They give generous proportions for all dishes and all dishes are GOOD 

This restaurant is also alot bigger than others too in tiny cramped Chinatown and this allows alot of comfortable space inside to sit with Alot of big sized family tables 

This is also a half served restaurant and also a small section that allowed you to order food and take out. They have trays and trays of heaping chicken and duck and everything that you can order to take out

Their menu is huge and is pretty much like a legit Chinese restaurant that has almost everything 

Great place for family, friends, kids
author: Cuc N.

description: I found the ambiance fascinating with the meat cleavers flailing about and the roast meat hanging in the window. Grungy place so it's not surprising the health inspector wasn't happy recently. Had two Chinese beers and a generous bowl of See Sum Fun soup which is just chicken noodle soup with some pork thrown in for $13.60 before tip and that includes tea. Soup was mild so I added chili sauce which they had out. Don't expect fast service because it's rather chaotic but that was the charm for me, a white guy from Wisconsin. Open tables mid-afternoon on a Sunday but it's a relatively large place. Worth a peek inside of nothing else of you haven't been to Chinatown before.
author: John M.

description:
This place is my grandparents' fave restaurant, and up to this day I still don't get why.

The restrooms are very dirty. Food is pretty average Chinese food. Nothing special about it. Our last time there, there was a hair in one of the sticky rice chicken dish. Gross.

My grandparents always rave about this place, and almost always picks this one for our big family dinners. 

I don't think I'll be attending anymore family dinners if it's held here.
author: Amy C.

description:
Came in the other day for dinner with a friend. They have a 3-entree + soup of the day deal for around $17, and it's a pretty good deal! (doesn't come with rice thou!)
I ordered their honey walnut shrimp, salt pepper eggplant, and seafood/tofu pot. Portions were generous. The honey walnut shrimp is pretty standard, it was really good and has just the right amount of sauce/mayonnaise. The salt pepper eggplant has a pretty thick batter, and was too greasy for me. The seafood pot was okay. It has squid, shrimp, tofu, mushroom, and fish. This place is family friendly and has big tables. Service was quick too. It is totally recommended for a dinner with the family.
author: Audrey H.

description:
If you're  looking for cheap good Chinese food, you should go here. Aesthetically the place looks sketchy inside but you can basically see the whole kitchen from your table. They have a separate menu which you can choose 3 items for $16.99 with big portions, probably good enough for 5 people. I give this place a 3.5. A la carte items range from $5-6.50. 

If you like pork, I really enjoyed the peking spare ribs. This is one of my favorite Chinese dishes. And for some green in your meal you should order bok choy with garlic. Simple but very tasty.
author: Thee N.

description: Simple, authentic, and inexpensive.  Perfect place to take to take the family.  We ordered one plate each ($7-9 each) and it was way too much food.  3 plates between the 5 of us would have been more than enough.
author: Bob R.

description:
I was reading the menu outside...

WTH!  $4 won tons?!!  Unheard of in San Francisco.  You had me at $4 won tons...

Ironically, we didn't end up ordering the $4 won tons.  Instead, we saw a meal deal.  

WTH!  3 items for $15.99?!!!  Holy crappers!  That's dirt cheap.  You had me at 3 for $15.99.  And that is what we ended up ordering.  

! - Shrimp with scramble eggs - it was a shame, this is one of my favorite dishes to eat.  The scramble eggs were over cooked or wasn't cooked the way I like them.  Usually, the eggs are soft and enhanced with chives with shrimp being the dominate flavor.  
! - Beef and Chinese broccoli - this actually came out good.  I thought the broccoli was cooked perfectly and was fresh.  
! - Seafood claypot - I guess you can't really go wrong with seafood clay pots.  They just dump everything in and cook it in some lovely sauce and BAM!  the flavors are all there.  This claypot had shrimp, calamari, cod fish, black mushrooms and 2 types of tofu.  

I thought the food was a tad salty and I ended up ordering a diet coke for burpage.  I wanted to make sure the MSG didn't hit my head right away, I think bubbly coke can prevent headaches and potential stomach aches.  Otherwise, the portions are huge, the food comes out quickly, and the service is typical to all Chinese restaurants.  Okay and can be better.

NOTES: Hole in the wall decor.  I saw fresh seafood swimming in a tank, so, it might be worth a try someday...especially with 'WTH' rock bottom prices.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I must say that reading thru numerous reviews here on this establishment, I was taken aback.

Upon entering this restaurant one is greeted by specials written with black marker and scotch taped to the walls....  expectations should be set accordingly.  If you want mother of pearl inlaid rosewood panels on the wall and gold chopstick rests with attentive service you should go to Tommy Toys.....  oh THATS right.....  all the cheap asians wouldnt pay the prices they charged to support that kind of superlative service so they closed.....they now expect it at Yee's for $9.99 entrees....interesting.....  

This being said my dinner companion and I came here in the late evening on a week night.  Lengthy standard menu and a three items for $19.99 special with complimentary soup.  VERY REASONABLE INDEED!  
All dishes provided were large portioned, hot and fresh (the shrimp in particular were large plump and crispy-fresh in the dishes requiring them).  Vegetables were fresh and the sauces sublte and flavorful.

As for the service, it was very good indeed.  Our waiter actually acknowledged smiled and greeted us.  I must say I almost lost my footing i was so taken aback at this behavior in Chinatown in the tourist area of Grant street.  Food was brought quickly, tea was replenished often, dishes cleared efficiently, and the waiter brought me EXTRA NAPKINS WITHOUT ASKING upon seeing they might be appreciated......  need i say more....

Very good experience.  I strongly recommend this establishment for an informal lunch or dinner for good food  and excellent service at a very good price
author: Charles S.

description: We have been coming for years! The fresh duck and roasted pig is something not too miss! The beer is ice cold and the service is like you were in China! If you look around and your the only white people in the place, you know the Chinese is going to be great!  The BBQ PORK served by the pound is also a great dish! Great value and a fun experience!
author: neal w.

description:
Dirty, below average chinese food. There was no one to seat us nor anyone to take our order unless we got up and asked for them. 

Left 3.5 as tip since we were not served well. Server stops us and demand for 5 saying it is required by US law lol.

Definitely not worth your time and appetite.
author: Xinwu Y.

description:
The restaurant looked decent from outside, so I was expecting to have some good food. But I was grated with some awful attitude from the server. Well, this is not my first time for this kind of situation, but I could generally stand this if the food is good. 

However, the food there tend out to be quite mediocre, or to be honest, much lower than even the average level of some Chinese fast food restaurant. So I was wondering why I had to stand the cold and unwelcome face of their waiter for this piece of shit. 

Ok, I would probably still give them two stars if that was just it. What made me so disgusted was their attitude when I paid. Tips? Ok, I would pay you some considering you still deliver my food to my table. $3ish, not that much but definitely not little considering the poor poor service. But the waiter apparently thought I was some visitor to the States and lied that the US law demanded $5 minimum for tips. Ok if you could lie about this, I m wondering how you actually treat your food and etc. So definitely one star for this, and I strongly discourage you to try this restaurant.
author: Ziyi Z.

description:
Yee's is one of my favorite restaurants in the world. It's a simple place where the local Chinese-American population get refueled. The food here is the star, and our favorites were the seasonal vegetables. Don't be put off by the Chinese-only writing on the walls, the menus are in English.

5 stars to Yee's incredible cuisine!
author: ArchaeoFiero S.

description:
Dude the best walnut prawn ever. I never like that dish in my life because it is just too American for me. All other restaurants fried the shrimp like tempura. But this 1 was done perfectly not too thick and crispy. And the Mayo isn't too sweet that I would get diabetes. It is the first time I actually like it. And the ginger chicken is awesome. 
It looks like a hole in the wall, but the food and the price is awesome.
author: Clement H.

description: This is a great place to go for some cheap, authentic Chinese food. You can tell by the low key setting and how the restaurant is always crowded and filled with Cantonese and Chinese speakers. We have been here several times, always on weekend nights, and they were always able to give us a table fairly quickly without a long wait. They have a huge and comprehensive menu, ranging from very affordable rice plates to some of the more specialty dishes. We were particularly impressed by the selection of congee they offered, which is more than we have seen at most restaurants. It's also great that they have some of the authentic Hong Kong style rotisserie meats. We have tried several congee bowls, the roast duck, crispy pork, and some other dishes. They were all delicious and and portions were very large.  The waiters were nice and efficient, and we were always happy with our dining experience there. Definitely keeping this restaurant on our list of low-key places to eat authentic Chinese food in Chinatown.
author: Sarah W.

description:
The Cantonese Roast Goose at Yee's is excellent.
After having roast goose in Hong Kong, I've been scouring North American Chinese restaurants for goose to no avail. So I was elated to discover this place on yelp. The goose here was moist, meaty, flavorful and was served in a sauce which smells pleasantly of cinnamon. Just as good as in HK.
The fried pigeon is, if anything, even better. Crispy and juicy, mostly boneless, it was some of the best fowl of any kind I've had. 

We also ordered a serving of broccoli which was more than ample.
author: Mike B.

description: I now consider Yee's Restaurant as one of my favorite go to restaurant... When I am at the San Francisco Chinatown Area!!! My most favorite rice plate that always like to order when I like sit back and relax and just forget about everything else!!! While eating my Mince Beef W/ Raw Egg Over Steam Rice!!! And I have mentioned this on my previous yelp review of Yee's Restaurant and I say it again... I have eaten at Yee's Restaurant so many many times over the years and I have never never experience any stomach aches or diarrhea when I finish eating at Yee's Restaurant...
author: William B.

description: We were in SF for 3 days and we dined here THREE TIMES!!!  We had a roast duck EVERY DAY!  That plus other fare of course!  Itis a fine establishment which was also close to our hotel... sigh.  WHat can I say?  The flavors were perfect and the staff actually cheerful and family-like with me/us!?  So... FIVE STARS!!!!
author: Tom G.

description:
Crispy pork, duck, won ton soup, jook, and red pork, everything here is so "typical Chinese" and just unbelievably delicious. If you are looking for a really tasty Chinese restaurant in San Francisco, this is your spot. It's super casual, so it's perfect if you want to pop in by yourself for a quick bite or come in with a big group. 

The won ton soup with noodles... it's just divine. It's possibly one of the best won ton soups I've ever had. Only made with the best ingredients in the tastiest hot broth. 

Crispy pork... that is such a treat. I'm not talking bacon here, I'm taking about a whole pig, roasted for hours where the skin is crispy crunchy and so delicious with the most delectable meat. This is no secret to the Chinese because on Chinese New Year's I saw whole pigs getting ready to be picked up or delivered. Dreaming about Yee's crispy pork and won ton soup.
author: Trisha W.

description: Delicious option in Chinatown with an extensive menu featuring traditional fare.  They feature cold Tsingtao which pairs great with their spicy dishes.  Friendly, quick service and pleasant atmosphere.  Be aware that they only accept cash.
author: Wild J.

description: Good food that is fairly priced. 3 plates for $21 plus rice feeds three people. Crowded, but that is to be expected in a cheaper place where many of the locals go.  This is not for dim sum or a nice relaxing atmosphere. This is to get full on as little money as possible. Think about it, 3 dishes and soup for $21. And I'm including tax too.
author: Peter K.

description:
There's no denying it. I love BBQ Pork. So when I was walking down Grant in Chinatown and saw Roasted Ducks and Pigs through Yee's Restaurant's front window, nothing could stop me from walking in.

So I picked up half a pound of BBQ Pork, grabbed some toothpicks, and out I went. Yum! Nothing like sightseeing with a box of BBQ Pork in my hands. I do have to say while I really liked the flavor of the marinade, some of it was a bit fatty which I don't like too much. Whatever. BBQ Pork!
author: Ray I.

description:
PLEASE DO NOT GO HERE. I REPEAT: DO NOT GO HERE.

My boyfriend has severe food poisoning and has been throwing up the past 2 hours since consuming the roasted goose from here. I only had 1 piece and am feeling okay, but he has been nauseated ever since. I had my suspicions about this place because when we walked in, they were handling the meats with their hands AFTER handling money exchanges with customers. Disgusting. Unsanitary. This place has been marked on Yelp as having a very low food safety score - yes, this should have been a tell tale sign. 

While we were there waiting for the food, the very rude butcher folks screamed at a woman in a Cantonese to get the he,k out of their restaurant because she didn't have money. The butcher woman with the short hair (looks like other Yelpers have reported her rudeness and not letting people out of the restaurant until they have tipped her) - it is the same woman who was screaming at the other older woman to get out of the restaurant.

Eat here at your own risk. 

I will be locating the SF food inspection website to alert them of this unsanitary restaurant. I beg of you, do not eat here.
author: Kristina K.

description:
I stumbled in here one evening after a North Beach pub crawl, and although I only stopped in to soak up the booze, I immediately fell in love with this place before I ever walked through the doors. For me, authenticity is a big part of my cultural dining experiences, I hate chain restaurants (for the most part), and yuppie twists on traditional dishes, which worked in my favor here, because this place bleeds authentic Cantonese fare. As soon as you approach this place, all your senses start working in unison with one another;faster and faster as you quickly become enveloped in this world of deliciousness. your eyes are immediately drawn to the beautifully roasted pork and poultry items hanging in the window and as you make your way further into the restaurant; you can see even more delicious  slow roasted items being sliced and sold per pound. 
   The scents that travel through the air in this restaurant are magnificent enough to lift you off your feet, I can't say that any one scent is more recognizable than the others, but I can say that the collective culmination of all these together; will have your nose begging for more. Once you taste the food, everything will start to make sense, you will see just exactly why this place is always busy. I literally love every item here, but the chicken chow mein is always a favorite of mine, it's always made to order, seasoned/prepared well, and very filling. Also, I like that they use thin noodles as opposed to thicker ones like many places around. Be sure to also try the pigeon, it's got an excellent flavor and about half as much grease/oil as the duck.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Like many Chinatown restaurants, it ain't fancy looking but Yee's Restaurant offers family style dinner (3 dishes, rice, and soup) for under $20 as well as a plethora of roast meats that are the subject of many tourists' photos on Grant Street. 

I've only eaten in once and I had the beef brisket wonton noodle soup. Adequately sized but I wished the bowl was bigger so I could have more soup. I was obviously hungover. All in all decent but nothing spectacular.

 Take-out is where it's at.

The big news here and my big tip... much of their roast meats and dishes go on sale around 3ish-4 in the afternoon. It's a popular deal with the elderly locals so you know it's got cred. Single plates for $2.25 or three for $6. I typically pick between the soy sauce chicken, roast pork, bbq pork, fried chicken but there are quite a few other choices. Point and choose and you're got quite the variety for dinner at home.
author: Jon L.

description: Filled with locals celebrating birthdays, the food was tasty, seemed fresh and well prepared, and tasted great!  We were looking for a good local Chinese restaurant and I think we found it.
author: Jay J.

description:
We ate here in a couples trip last year lured in by the ducks hanging in the window.  

This year came back with the kids on a family trip.  Grabbed a duck and some pork to go this time and couldn't be more happy.  Love love love the duck.  Skin is crispy and meat is tender!
author: Anita A.

description:
I really liked this restaurant. The food is cheap and absolutely authentic.

I normally have high standards for Chinese food and let me say that this place did not disappoint. It is also super cheap - when can you find such cheap Chinese food (for both lunch and dinner prices) in Seattle? Walking around Chinatown in San Francisco made me very upset - majority of the Chinese restaurants have super cheap dishes there!

My friend and I had the 3-dish special for $16.99 and the food was delicious. The portion is huge and my friend and I could barely finish half of the food we ordered (NO KIDDING). It also came with a complimentary Chinese soup dish - I am not sure what the name of the soup dish was but the soup was tasty. For the 3-dish special thing, I had to order rice as a side dish for $1 per bowl - but the amount was huge! 

I think I can understand how other yelpers would give such low ratings because of bad services. I normally really look into services as well. But (fortunately?) the services were not particularly bad during my visit and I would come back again.
author: Maria G.

description:
Wandering around chinatown and found this place. Ordered roasted duck - 80% of the duck they gave us was fat and bones. Skin wasn't crispy. Also ordered fried squid, too much batter, too greasy. 

Beef brisket noodle was alright, probably the healthiest thing we ordered haha. 

Overall, the restaurant wasn't very sanitary, they had a bunch of little plates sitting out for their 3-5pm afternoon special. The special is a very good deal, but it's just not sure if I would want to eat that. 

I wasn't expecting much out if this place so 3 stars is sufficient.
author: ChingWa C.

description: Nice staff! Great food selection if you like  authentic Chinese cuisine. BBQ pork is to die for!!
author: Nate E.

description:
In two short trips to SF, I've found Chinatown to be right up my alley. I was hobbling on one foot, having sprained an ankle, but my wife and I weren't going to stop until we found some barbecue pork.

We ordered some chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, barbecue pork, and roast duck. Portions were huge, the meal was cheap, and we got exactly what we came for. The veggies are not to be skipped. Order that broccoli!

The duck and the bbq pork were both excellent, and served over some cabbage with rice. I wish I could bring this place back home.
author: Dylan B.

description: While the health score of 83 does not instil confidence, this little hole in the wall hit the right spot for a couple young starving folks.
author: Drew W.

description:
It's in Chinatown +

They all sqawked some Cantonese dialect +

BBQ meats hanging in the window +

Equally as clean as an equivalent in Vancouver, meaning dirty floors and kinda filthy looking = 

AUTHENTIC.

So I stroll in.  Ordered chicken chow mein for my daughter and curry beef brisket.  Also came with the standard soup of the day like at most Chinese eateries.

Soup.  It was some kind of melon soup, with pork and nuts.  Bland as F.U.C.ing hell.  There was no flavour in this at all.

Chicken chow mein
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/yees-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tLAMpmsmiDO6PBn_OhBFtg#BBWhy2iWi2LADicmzqIwcA
This was not good either.  It was prepared in a similar manner to food court chow mein.  I did the ordering in Canto.  I have no idea how I ended up with this plate prepared in this style.  Didn't matter to my daughter, she ate it.

Curry beef brisket.
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/yees-restaurant-san-francisco#oWyURDE-mEI86THVI4fYdA
This was actually quite good.  The spicing in the curry was quite flavourful and had a nice amount of heat, but not overwhelming.  I would come back for this dish.
author: Herman E.

description:
Call this the hidden gem of mom and pop Chinese food restaurant.  Nestled in historic Chinatown is Yee's Restaurant.  From the outside, this place looks like a dirty, dirty dive place.  A place where you mother would advice you not to enter since it does not look clean.  However, if you can escape that stereotype, Yee's restaurant serves excellent food.  

My friends did the ordering since I do not speak Chinese (bad Asian).  We ordered Chinese cabbage, a noodle dish and goose.  Yes, I said goose.  What does goose taste like?  It taste like duck, but not as fatty.  I can review the other dishes we ordered but the goose was the absolute winner.  Juicy and tender and not fatty.  I could order a whole goose for myself and not share it with my friends.  And, guess what?  It wasn't that expensive.  

As for the ambiance and décor, it is a dive restaurant.  I did wipe my tableware with my napkin (force of habit). The service here is good.  Our server kept coming around to check on us.

Like all diamonds in the rough, they are hard to find.  But, when you find one, you know you found an investment.
author: Dean N.

description:
I'll make this short and sweet.  This place is amazing!

1. Cheap prices:  This place is extremely affordable, even for the cash strapped.  Definitely a plus in San Francisco, where almost everything is expensive.

2. Quality:  For the cheap prices, you get amazing food.  I had the goose noodle soup and it was delicious.  The goose itself was perfectly cooked and very tasty.  I sampled my some of the roast duck noodle soup, the chicken noodle soup, and the BBQ pork noodle soup (all with flat rice noodles) and all were amazing.  The meats here are really top notch.  

3. Portion size:  For the aforementioned low prices, you get a huge amount that will leave you very, very full and satisfied.  If you get the noodle bowls, they'll give you a large amount of meat and plenty of noodles.  You will definitely leave here weighing a little more than when you entered.

4.  Service isn't really anything too great honestly.  After getting our food, it took forever for them to refill our tea pot once we emptied it and raised the lid.  However, we got our food really fast, so that's what mattered to us the most.  

Basically, this place is a great value, but after getting your food quickly, expect to play "catch the waitstaff" for anything else.
author: Christine W.

description:
3 stars just because it wasn't spectacular but it wasn't awful- just average.

I came here with family before noontime so it wasn't busy at all, only a couple other tables were occupied. I ordered the roasted duck wonton noodle soup and for the portion, the price was pretty good. For about $7-8 you get a full bowl of about 5 wontons and a whole lot of roast duck which was pretty tasty. 

However, above all, it's not something I would rave about, just something mediocre if you need a quick wonton noodle soup fix or just noodles. It's pretty cheap so I mean, why not? 

The workers were nice and the food came out fairly quickly, but that might be because of the fact that it wasn't busy.
author: Vi D.

description: Well what a great place to eat while in San Francisco.  I ate here twice in my week here. The place doesnt look like very much from the outside but the food and value for money is excellent.  Quick service and very good staff.
author: John N.

description:
Yee's had 2 tables of roasted turkey available with pricing on them ($42, $37, $38, etc). 

menu: 3 fer deals, bbq deli items, rice plates, usual chinatown menu, white board specials. 

eats: won ton soup (4)
-14 won tons, with lettuce in salty msg broth
bland meat, bland crunchy shrimp
msg attack afterwards though i drank very little broth
$$ value-4 stars, food value-2 stars.

leftovers:
-msg use may be heavy here.
-good value but poor tasting
-food took a while to show up.
-skipping the food next time,  deli unsure...
author: Victor G.

description: Wow, this place is not a romantic date spot for sure. But if you want no frills, just good chinese eats, you need to go here. Damn I will travel from Haight to North Beach to get take out from this place. Try the roast goose, roast pork, salt and pepper fish, and i  love that pork/wonton soup. Just blindfold yourself and pick something off the menu, you'll still most certainly end up with a great choice! Go Yee's
author: Rouz E.

description: At this point this place has become a family tradition. No matter where we're traveling, even if we have a day layover in SF we make it a point to dine here. Great authentic meals! Very traditional, fast paced dining and an adventure. Love this place!
author: Ruth J.

description: Came with my family to eat. The food was okay, but took around 30 minutes to bring 1 or 2 dishes. Then one dish hasn't came within 45 minutes, after my family told them the situation, then another 15 minutes later, they still haven't brought it. So we just told them to not cook it at all and just left. Definitely wouldn't come back to this restaurant.
author: Steve L.

description: Food quality was average. Ordered the bbq pork rice noodle soup. Soup was oily with a few green onions sprinkled on top. Not the best but for the price it was medicore at best.
author: Mai T.

description:
My husband's grandmother lives around the area and we always walked by this place seeing those roast duck and roast pork hung behind the glass.  On this trip with my parents, we finally got to try this place.  There was this dinner special where you can order 3 items for $16.99.  With my mother in law, there were 5 adults so we ordered 6 dishes plus a roast duck.

To my surprise the dishes that came out were super huge!  We thought $16.99 for 3 items, the portion would be small but nope it was a full dinner portion.  We were saying in OC, 1 dish is probably around $12.  So $16.99 for 3 items is a steal!

The food was very tasty.  Their salted pepper wings are super tasty!  My husband's grand aunt would order 10lbs when she comes to visit SF.  They served all wings and no drummettes at all unlike some restaurants tell you chicken wings but they included the drummettes.  Their roast duck is super juicy and definitely fattening.  We also ordered a fried flounder with sauce and the fish was huge.  Everything was very good for a very good price.

Around evening time, they would chop up all the roasted stuff and sell it for $2.50 per plate.  You see a lot of people come in to pick up the plate to add for dinner.  

Decor wise, this place isn't like 5-star decoration but the food is really good.  I saw they have roast goose and would like to try it next time when we visit.

Note: this place is cash only!

-------------
Almost forgot to add, we tried their breakfast menu.  We had the congee and stir fry soy noodle.  Both very good and very Chinese breakfast too!
author: Abbe W.

description:
It's excellent restaurant for roasted duck, pork in affordable price. The waiters are all polite and keep smiling. I had never visited a Chinese restaurant with all the people keeping a smiling faces. Not many tables there, but a lot of people buying to go order, then you know the food there is really good. 

The bad, 
toilet is not really clean. but, who cares, I am not gonna eating things inside :).
author: Swergar T.

description: We visited this restaurant in a trip to San Francisco in July 2016. We were advised by a friend that there is a place that we can eat real Chinese food and it was so. The restaurant might be in poor health but the food is what you can find in China and most of the costumers seemed Chinese. The portion of the food was large and the price was around 7 bucks for it. We ordered a bowl of sower sweet soup, a plate of noddles, and fish. I recommend the soup.
author: Azita R.

description: OMG!  If you are here in china town visiting you need this to be where you eat!  The portions are for a small army but all so good.  $18.99 will feed 6 people!
author: Tessa C.

description: Went with friends for a banquet dinner. The food is solid, portions are ample and the prices are reasonable. One dish in particular was the abalone with gai lan; the abalone was sliced thin, but in rarher large pieces, the gai lan was in very large pieces about 6 inches long. This made for a little awkward eating. The BBQ items were spot on, as was the flounder/sole. The orange wedges for dessert were really sweet! Service was fairly decent. They had  sign up near the register about free parking. They offer marked down items after 5pm.
author: Dennis Y.

description: Yee's makes a killer salted chicken (not really salty at all). You can 1/4 chicken, rice, streamed veggies, and great homemade house soup for $4.25++. The chicken is cooked perfectly and the breast is extremely tender. Alternatively, try the soy sauce chicken for a bit more savory flavor. This place is always packed with locals, and it can get quite busy during peak hours, but it is well worth it for the food and ambience. Another excellent lunch under5bux addition!
author: Brian J.

description: I can't tell you how the food tastes. They do not take food allergies seriously. I asked the waiter to ask the chef if the food that I am allergic to was in the food I ordered.  He said he didn't think so. I told him I need to know so I don't get ill. He wouldn't ask. I got up and left.
author: Micah C.

description: Was craving some slimy chow fun with beef and veggies for the past couple of days and found this place on Yelp. Also got a char siu rice with veggies for my husband. Char siu was fatty, tender, and sweet, with just the right amount of crunchiness at the charred ends. Chow fun was slimy - could've been a little more veggie-heavy but still satisfying. Their chicken thighs in the window looked amazing - I would try that next time, plus they have a lot of seafood dishes written on the wall in Chinese. For $13 including the complementary soup, this place is pretty great. If you want fancy bathrooms, try Crystal Jade.
author: Andrea P.

description: Food is the real deal        fresh hot and good          service was quick        bathroom wasnt pretty but who cares      id eat here 4x a week if i lived here
author: David B.

description:
What a memorable evening. We combined a great Chinese banquet dinner with the SF Giants winning Game 3 of the World Series during our dining experience. After the Giants win, our table cheered the loudest. Our foodie friend organized a group of us comprising of eleven individuals for this great meal.

The showcase featured a suckling pig. It was roasted perfectly.  Tender pork morsels with very crispy pork skin.  The pig was cut into bite size pieces and pieced back together.

The restaurant paced it so that we could enjoy the pig at a leisurely pace.  The our other dishes came out accordingly.

The other highlight dish was the quail.  As with other fowl, usually the head and the tail is kept and served.  This quail was deep fried and presented whole with the head attached.  That's a first for me.  The quail was very moist.  

We had a total of eight courses and all were scrumptious.  

What the restaurant lacked in ambiance it made up for with the food.  Maybe it helped that my foodie friend is a regular here.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Whenever I'm in S.F., I never know a good Chinese place to eat at.  I happened upon this place, looked at the menu, and peeked inside.  

I just felt like a bowl of won ton soup with noodles and cha shu.  For $5, it was such a big bowl with a good broth, an adequate number of won tons, plenty of noodles, some napa, and a very generous portion of cha shu slices on top.  What a bargain!!  This is definitely a place for good and cheap eats!
author: Julie F.

description:
I've been coming here frequently because the food is tasty and the portions are generous.  The price is right.   The negatives are:  the service--inattentive and slow if you take too long to decide what you want --it seems to throw a kink into their assembly line service.  If you're not ready to order, they go away and forget about you until you have to flag them down.  No checking in on you, no refilling of tea or water.  And forget about ordering take out!!  If you call in your order and say you'll be picking up in half an hour and they respond, yes it'll be ready.  Come by, 40 min later and they STILL have to COOK part of the order.  What's up with that??  I spent 15 minutes waiting, double parked, for a pick up ordered almost an hour ago.  I would have better luck coming in to eat.  This has happened twice before when ordering takeout.  They make you wait as if they weren't sure you were going to show up so the chef gets the order only when you come in to pay.
Why give a time frame for pickup if you're not going to have it ready???
author: mizzy b.

description:
When I was in college, I used to volunteer for he CNY fesitvals. The Chinese Chamber of Commerce usually treats us to lunch for our help. I remember we could order anything off the menu - for a starving college student, that's a good thing. Their chow mein and other dishes were excellent. 

Today, after more than 20 years, I come back here with my family for an assn lunch. This was a full 8 course meal - Peking ribs, walnut shrimp, ginger chicken, lobster and crab the works. Food portions were ginormous. Everything came out in big platters. I really loved the walnut shrimp. Not too heavy on the mayo and the nuts were crunchy!

Yes place is dive-y but it makes up in food. They also have a deli take out section. This is the best place to eat in C-town when you're on a budget!
author: Wendy H.

description: Authentic Chinatown experience, and amazing cuisine!  A MUST STOP if you're in Chinatown, SF, CA.
author: Eyrie Jammer D.

description: Went lunches with co-worker. Lunch time is crowded and noisy, needs to share table with others. But still going for the good number of options on the menu/wall, low price and authentic Chinese (Cantonese) dishes. They re-modeled the floor and price were not changed, surprisingly.
author: Tina A.

description:
Compare to other restaurants in Chinatown, the services here are decent.  They're actually nice.  Their portion are huge.  The prices are decent as well.  

My friend and I ordered the wonton soup, beef pan fried noodle, BBQ pork & roast duck over rice and a can soda.  All these for under $20.  

The taste wise, it was only ok but decent for the price.  I would probably come here again next time I'm in SF.
author: Susan B.

description: The food is usually good but when my wife check out the chicken and its cleanliness she said she did not want to eat here again.  A health score of 53 confirms this so we will stay away til they clean it up.
author: Mike N.

description:
3.5 stars

Wow is what I said when I walked into Yee's. There was food on tables, food on the counter, all for the grabbing at 2-3 bucks each. It is premade food left for customers to just grab, pay and go. My friends and I opted for the 3 entrees for 20 bucks deal which was definitely a recession buster.

We had ordered walnut shrimp, Mongolian beef, and Hainese chicken. We had also grabbed some fried chicken from the ala carte tables for 3 bucks. The walnut shrimp and Mongolian beef were my favs. They had tons of flavor and tasted very fresh. I love it when beef is tender with every bite and not dry. The walnut shrimp had the perfect amount of mayo and the walnuts were definitely candied. However, the Hainese chicken was boring and bland. I have never been a fan of it and just never had good steamed or poached chicken. The fried chicken was cold, cold, and mushy. It was a waste of 3 bucks lol...

The service was good and the place was definitely filled with customers hitting up the ala carte tables. The complimentary soup was just msg water but tasted more like tasteless water. I would come back again for the 3 entree deal but skip the ala carte tables because you don't know how long those little dishes have been sitting there. See my pictures to see what I mean.
author: Danster L.

description:
Came here for family dinner and the food was complete crap. Bland. Flavorless. & Leftovers.  3 words that literally summed up ALL of the dishes. The best thing I had that night were the oranges they served.

Fish - came out very undercooked, had to send it back to re-cook it. Still wasn't even good

quail - taste like leftover chicken. extremely dry

sweet and sour pork - not sour nor sweet enough. too bland

honey walnut shrimp - walnuts were stale, shrimp were overly drenched in the mediocre sauce

Had a bunch of other dishes, but since everything was terrible already, I don't even want to bother with the details. 

Completely regret coming here. My parents could've made all these things 10x better at home.
author: Harriet W.

description: This place looks  like a foodies paradise with the ducks being displayed at the window but shall I caution you that the food isn't that great. I would suggest Hong Kong Clay Pot down the street. Cheap prices, horrible service (waited 40 min for my food ) and  food wasn't good. I ended up taking most of the food to go and giving it to a homeless person. They get a one star for multiple reasons... First being they brought out a wrong plate, but after waiting I accepted it Bc I was starving.... Secondly, the cashier told my husband he better leave a tip on the table... For what? Horrible service, wrong order and nasty food? Needless to say, we left without tipping due to the pushy cashier.
author: Franchesca S.

description:
This restaurant only deserves one star for the honey walnut prawns and cheap prices for food. This restaurant is terrible with service and need more servers and someone to ensure meals are coming out in order based on when people have arrived.

My group arrived at the restaurant with no one to greet us or guidance on how seating was arranged. It looked like a busy restaurant but there were some open tables. I had to approach the lady working and ask if we had to seat ourselves or if someone would show us where we would sit. We already had a prediction that the service was not going to be good based on previous experiences at Asian restaurants but not that terrible! It took them awhile to give us plates and hot tea but they did not ask if we wanted anything else to drink - not even water. We finally got our order in and then we were wondering why there was such a long wait. Also we noticed a Chinese family sitting a table next to us come in after us and already get served soup and their entrees and our table didn't get one thing. We also noticed a table behind us that was NOT Chinese and they also got their food late around the same time we finally received our food. Other tables around us that were Chinese did get their food and came in after us. We should be treated the same way and get our food at a fair time prior to people that have already come in after us. The waiter also did not update us on why the food was taking a long time. At this point, after seeing others that came in after us get all their food, being hungry, not receiving good service, we were close to walking out but then we got our food and it was piping hot so it shows that our food was fresh off pan but it really does not take that long to cook shrimp fried rice, TERRIBLE "Mongolina" beef or whatever that was, salt and pepper chicken that only had legs available and no wings, and honey walnut prawns. Overall, our food was $25.55 so I gave the cashier $26 and left.
Do NOT come to this restaurant if you expect good service, great food, and fair treatment based on your ethnicity.
author: Antoinette H.

description:
My wife and I decided to eat here on a whim based on our hunger.  We ordered the soy sauce chicken, roast duck, and Chinese broccoli.  

The chicken -  flavorful, moist , succulent.  5 stars!

Duck - had better.  They limited the amount of breast meat and was a little salty for our take.

Broccoli - salty with the oyster sauce but better when coupled with rice.

Service - typical.  Not too friendly - never want to go out of their way.  

Surprisingly we have had better duck in Dallas so essentially we don't recommend it unless you are really hungry like we were.
author: Art R.

description:
I typically dine at Yee's once every other month.  Living 60 miles away, always look forward to a great tasting and affordable meal.   

We ordered the 3 item lunch special, comes with complementary house soup. The soup was watered down, so bad we didn't touch it. 

When the main course was served, one item was not what was ordered.
Decided not to make a big deal and enjoy the meal.  Few minutes later the waiter came by (without explanation) gave us the correct item and took what we were eating to the other customer.

Overall the taste (favor, temperature, portion) and service was lacking compared to past experience.
author: Benn H.

description: NEVER GO HERE EVER even in wake of an apocalypse and Yee is standing at the door greeting you with piles of noodles DO NOT TAKE THEM. I ate pan fried noodles here and was deathly ill from food poisoning the day after. Had to go to the ER and get hooked up to an IV. Do not submit yourself to Yee's wrath
author: Trace T.

description:
Not sure how my parents discovered this place but the past few years they've been bringing out of town guests to Yee's. Some Chinese-American friends also randomly took me here and I just wondered how people would find this place out of the hundreds of restaurants in Chinatown - not all restaurants with hanging ducks are created equally. It's a little less touristy since it's on the northern end, almost in North Beach. 

When my family goes, everyone orders the $4 wonton noodle soup and then share the roast meats on the side - duck, pork, pork spare ribs, soy sauce chicken. I always hope the broth will be better but it is pretty unremarkable and bland. The wontons are decent and plump. Just add the meats to help flavor the broth. The roast duck is obviously oily but the ducks they use aren't grossly fatty. The other meats are flavorful and tender. Everyone eats for less than $10/person including a good tip.

They also have a 3 item special for under $20 for a lot of typical Cantonese dishes. You can feed 3-5 people this way. Jook is delicious and cheap. One of my fave dishes ended up being a simple shrimp egg omelet which was well seasoned and thin yet not overcooked. Around 2 or 3 pm, they start setting out small dishes of their excess roast meats and other dishes for a few bucks. They've started wrapping the dishes individually with saran wrap so people aren't breathing all over the food as they forage. 

Service can be pretty bad. You think the waiter is totally looking at you but when you start talking to them they walk away. So no shame in vigorously flagging someone down.
author: Mimi L.

description: cash only. bad service. BBQ duck is too salty. CHEAP, very CHEAP, of course don't expect 5 star quality when it's that cheap. They have afternoon special with chinese BBQ dishes, I think its $2.70 a dish. YES dumb ass cheap... but very greasy and salty...
author: Kris J.

description:
We like coming whenever we're in China Town because service is decent, food quality good and prices per dish are very cheap.  

It's amazing how you can get a meal plate for only $5 (portions are quite big).  You can't find cheaper and good quality anywhere.  

It's usually busy at lunch but we did come here last Sunday for dinner and was seated immediately. 

What we ordered:
1 Singapore vermicelli curry 
1 Lotus root with pork
1 wonton soup with BBQ pork
1 large beer
All of this came to about $23.  Oh, and they even give you slices of oranges after your meal. 

Definitely a place to try if you've never been.  I guarantee you won't be disappointed with the food.
author: Rosetta C.

description:
This place has really gone down in value. The Roast Pork used to be really good now it tastes very bland in flavor and just salty. The goose is decent but not much of an expert on that since I usually only get it from this place. 

Other than the roast pork and the goose, the food here is expensive and just tasteless.  The portions are pretty small for the price you are paying. They ding you for everything like rice and tea. Maybe it is an SF thing but I am from LA and rice comes with your food, especially if your food is so freakn expensive. Also it takes a long time for the food to come out.
