Last but not least,  remember the server brought a dish and spilled the sauce from the food on the table close to my parents cause he was careless. I understand that but the least he could have done was say sorry or attempt to clean it up. Nope just left it there on the table.
author: Willis W.

description: Picked up 1lb. Barbeque pork (char siu). Decent, not extraordinary. Think it was actually too lean. Ok service. Cannot complain. Will try others next time.
author: Cari S.

description: After walking around Chinatown for a while on our 1st day in San Francisco looking for a place to have dinner, we stumbled upon this very reasonably priced cantonese style BBQ restaurant. You can order the BBQ meats hanging in the window by the plate ($8-9), or order 1 or 2 meats over rice ($5-8). The food was pretty good and this place did get crowded on the Saturday night we were here. This place is cash only, like most of the places in Chinatown so don't come with just plastic! I would definitely return again if in San Francisco! We actually tried coming a few days later but it was too late in the evening and they had already closed (8:30ish pm)
author: Brian P.

description: We usually eat at Grant Place but had wanted to try Yee's since we couldn't get a table the last time we were in town. We got in right at noon and could get a table. The waiter was a bit slow in taking our order but the roast duck and roast pig were great. We also got the mixed veggies and an order of wonton noodle soup. Also very good. You can tell a restaurant is good in China town when they have the roast ducks hanging in the window. The price was under $35.00 for all of this which I consider a good deal. No dim sum, though, like Grant Place but we enjoyed the food and had a little to take home. By 12:30 there was a line out the door so get there early.
author: Lee O.

description:
Best roast pork I've ever had.  

Even my parents say that they've only the tasted the same flavor only in China/Hong Kong.

I make exclusive trips to Nor Cal just for this!!!
author: David W.

description:
Actually, this place is pretty good. I grew up Cantonese, so this reminds me of Cantonese down-home cooking. My parents and I come up to The City about once a month, and we've been here a few times. If my picky mother likes a place, then the quality measure is high and "they must be good."

Like someone said here - "soul food Chinese style" - and I think that they're pretty right-on, esp for the price.

We always get our roast pork from the deli here, and I'd venture to guess that the pigs that they use to roast seem smaller/younger, thus making the meat more tender and smooth, rather than the rough cardboard texture that you might get with an older/larger pig. It's almost always got the right amount of fat and the skin is consistently thick and crispy.

This might be considered a hole-in-the-wall, but I think is considered a step-above.
i.e. 
no grime on the walls and a wait-staff that sits you down and serves you the food ;-)

I've only tried one thing here, and that is the - ngow nam mein - fatty beef brisket/belly with thin egg noodles in soup. Not sure if it's on the menu, but my mom usually tells the waiter that's what we want. All I can say is that it comes out really good, and I think for what you get at $4.95 (the price that I remember), you get a good healthy bowl of it!

I think that if you confidently know what you want (from having grown up Chinese!), and don't have reservations about ordering something that's not on the menu, see if they can do it! 

Through the grapevine, I have heard that you can order (gee yuk biang) steamed pork hash if you ask for it!
author: Jimmy L.

description:
My father-in-law is a Chinese restaurant chef in Chicago and all he could do was rave about this place.  He made the claim that their menu items taste just like when he was back in Hong Kong.

Duck noodles, salty pork congee and thousand year egg congee for $15 was a steal and fed 5 people happily!

Flat noodles and tripe to go were about $2 a pound.  Very, very tasty.

For dinner we ordered salt and pepper flounder, honey walnut shrimp and a vegetable dish... $15.99.

A whole goose is $32.
author: Cathaleya C.

description: Roasted goose. Only place in San Francisco that has roasted goose. Super cheap and super quick service. Their chinese bbq ribs are good. I would never order from the tables though that the food on the tables are not clean. and random customers touch and prod at the plates. I would definitely not recommend getting those unless you see the butcher put them down fresh.
author: Janet D.

description:
It is correct to call this place authentic (dirty, walls plastered with menu items but written only in Chinese). But authentic is not always a good thing.

The good: Cheap and huge portions. We paid $40 (after tax and tip) for eight people and struggled to finish everything.

The bad: The place is dirty.
The food is just salty and greasy. I can't be sure if they used a lot of MSG, but they might as well have.
author: AloisSchicklgruber H.

description:
I saw this place on Food Network after we went there. Great food..owner a lil suspect, but great food. lol. 
If you go to Chinatown in San Fran, you gotta hit this spot...hey...what happen to our coke...he forgot again. dang...
author: Duvell D.

description:
Yee's seems to get a lot of flak about the overall cleanliness of the restaurant... so to start off my 5-star review, I've added a disclaimer:

As a general rule at Canto restaurants, you just don't ask about the details of your food, as any honest answer is probably undesirable, ie:

"Is the pigeon meat fresh?"
"Yes... probably. Locally-grown too."

I personally love this place with all my heart. This is as authentic & tasty as Chinese food gets north of the Silicon Valley. Don't be fooled by its "touristy" location on Grant Ave. If you can't read Chinese, it's going to be pretty hard to order anything. 

As a college student, I'm a sucker for the 3 for $15 meals, complete w/ soup, fruit & tea. My favorite 3 for $15 items are the salt&pepper pork spareribs, (fatty, salty, peppery soul food at its best) the ginger-scallion fried tilapia ($5 whole fish... enough said) the dry-cooked sichuan string beans, and the seafood-veggie pot (bubbling hot w/ bok choy, various mushrooms, fried soft tofu, squid & fish.) 

I've never gotten sick off the food; my (disclaimer: white) fiance has been here countless times and he's never gotten sick/nauseous either. I've taken my extended family here, and they all love it & agree that this sort of authentic Canto food can hardly be found anymore... :( Plus, when you branch off the $15 3-course meal and loosen your purse strings a little, the food is excellent! Stewed clams, tender braised pork, perfectly roasted duck... Yee's has an orgiastic selection of meats that correctly earned it mention in Frommers as one of the best Chinese "meat delis" in SF.

For the strong-stomached... keep coming. :) There's this incredible feeling of validation you get when you've come for the umpteenth time and the manager actually deigns to flash you a smile... it's as if you're one of them now! And when that happens, the food comes promptly, the orders aren't mixed up and you're even honored with a scrap or two of meat & squash floating in your complimentary soup. Major bragging rights for an ABC.

On the flip side, you should gauge your dining companions carefully before taking them here. As much fun as it is to introduce everyone & their mom to culinary Asia, it can be disconcerting to order your meal (over a formica tabletop plus the din of 100 other hungry, loud diners) and have it come out with head, innards & ovaries attached. Yee's is delicious, but the dining experience isn't for everyone. That being said, if you're Chinese, you have to like it. Seriously... it's like your birthright. 

Tips: Come early during the day if you want fish- they sell out fast. Be nice & order in Chinese (if you can.) Try everything- it's all yummy. And...

Bottom Line: In the words of Josh D'Aluisio-Guerrieri- "Find comfort in the fact that a billion people eat at places like this every day, but it isn't solving the probblem of overpopulation."
author: Tianyi S.

description:
Came here with 3 other people the other day. A co-worker of mine told me this place has a really good lobster yee mein. When we looked at the special menu, there was a $15.99 deal for 3 dishes. It looked pretty good so we picked salt and pepper shrimp, green bell pepper beef, and garlic baby bok choi. We also ordered the lobster yee mein too. 

The food itself was definitely worth it. It came with free soup and we had rice with the dishes. Between the four of us we couldn't finish all the food and we're big guys. Extra plus for the prompt service because our waiter was ready to take our order and the food came out quick. I liked the lobster but there wasn't a whole lot of meat in it. I was pleasantly surprised that they include the shell. It was stir fried and battered with the noodles. 

I'll be back to try the other items on the menu. There is quite an extensive list and it's recommended that you bring several people along or else you won't finish the food.
author: Tim G.

description:
What a great looking display window!!!  I took a pic just cause it looked so yummy! :)

My friends and I stopped in today for some lunch.  It was quite busy because of the Moon Festival but they were able to seat us with minimal wait.  The lady who prepared our table was friendly (which is not so common in some Asian joints) and so I was quite happy with our random lunch restaurant choice.  I was even more pleased when she told us to pick 3 items and for 15$.  Wow!  What a deal. :)  We didn't really use that menu though because everything was had great prices.  

We ordered 4 dishes.  The first to arrive was a preserved egg porridge which was great!  Everyone at the table really liked it, even our '1st time to China town friend'. Haha.  Next up was combination noodles.  The meats and seafood in the noodles were very good but the noodles themselves were way too salty.  We picked at the noodles after we finished the porridge and then waited for our roast duck/bbq pork and soy sauce chicken.... and waited and waited and waited... 

It took us a while to flag down nice lady but when we did she immediatly went to prepare our duck and pork.  We finished that and decided to go ahead and go, though the soy sauce chicken hadn't arrived. 

All in all, I'd definitely go back.  The food was good and everything was under 20$!!  I think the forgetfulness was just because it was so busy with the festival.  The nice lady even apologized., though we weren't really put out by the wait... which again, I don't expect in an Asian restaurant. Haha!  

I bet next time I go it's a 4 or 5 star!  I'll update...
author: Susan D.

description: Terrific place!  We come here every Xmas night for the roasted goose in the window! Amazingly cheap delicious Xmas dinner!
author: Chrys K.

description:
I think not!

Yes, I think a lot of their food was good and cheap but lemme tell you something...I've only had bad food diarrhea from two places: 1) Once from food in a supermarket in China. 2) Here at Yee's Restaurant. 

Maybe this was a fluke since this was my first time here. On the other hand, my cousin that I went with got diarrhea the same time as I did.
author: Dennis H.

description: Hugh portion with good price!  Food is Cantonese style.  We had special sauce chicken which taste well and chicken meat is not tough.  Veggies dishes are average.  Nice place for large group and save money.
author: Yue Wing C.

description:
So the first time I went here, I was too distraught to truly appreciate the awesomeness of Yee's (my good friend bought me here following a bad break up and to get me out of the house for Chinese New Year). Somehow it took me over a year to come back to this place.  How did I not realize they had the best deal ever of three dishes for $15.99?! We added a fourth dish and some beverages and the bill came out to just over $30. We were all stuffed for $10 per person including tip. 

The food is tasty and the service swift and friendly and the prices are amazing -- how can you go wrong?! The salt and pepper flounder is my favorite, but I also enjoyed the honey walnut shrimp, beef with chinese broccoli, and ginger chicken (and I vaguely recall the roasted duck briefly pulling me out of my dull drums on the first visit, but don't quote me on that).
author: Dani D.

description:
Service is mediocre, like it is at most Chinese restaurants.

I got the wonton noodle soup ($4.00). There were a lot a shrimp, so I was happy. For the price? Hell yeah! They ran out of duck, which my friend ordered. The kung pao chicken was apparently a little bland (according 3 out of 4 at the table), so for those who like drizzling your shit with soy sauce, you're going to need a lot more. I thought it was fine. 

Bonus: a slice of watermelon for dessert. YESSSSS!
author: Cathy N.

description:
Our family stopped here yesterday on a quick trip into the city.  I found this restaurant via another site's recommendation (I felt guilty for cheating on Yelp, of course) -- it fit the bill for location, price range and ratings, and if we go somewhere unfamiliar without a destination in mind, we tend to wander aimlessly until we finally turn on each other in a low-blood-sugar rage, like crazed jackals.  

Yee's was not the absolute best Chinese food I've ever had in my life (that was in a hole-in-the-wall somewhere in the city which I'll never find again ... sort of a Brigadoon thing, I suspect), but it was very good.  Everyone found something they liked, there was a wide variety of dishes, the waiter was helpful, the food wasn't greasy (one of my pet peeves), we didn't feel rushed or ignored even though it was close to closing time, and the price?  Phenomenal.  Four of us -- all big strapping corn-fed hearty eaters of Chinese food -- ate until we were stuffed, with two containers of leftovers, for *forty dollars*.  Srsly.  

- Pot stickers:  these were the weakest link, since they were sort of doughy, but the flavor was excellent and the price was right
- Char siu:  big portion, very juicy, holds up favorably to my companion's exacting char siu standards (he's kind of a char siu maven)
- Eggplant with salted fish and chicken:  the waiter warned us that this was "smelly", but we braved it.  Smelly, yes, but the flavor is good and the eggplant's flavor and texture were especially nice
- Some kind of rice noodle dish with beef:  again, great flavor; a little light on the beef
- Mongolian beef:  excellent, albeit an awful lot of onions
- Green beans with minced pork:  fantastic!  spicy without being overwhelming, more meat than we expected (and little slices of pork, not hamburger-sized-crumbly-bits as the name might suggest

They brought us some amazing melon (in lieu of fortune cookies) with the check, which made a good contrast to the meal.  Also, free melon! 

I'd definitely recommend Yee's just for the food, but the location is also excellent -- easy to find (near Grant and Columbus) and close to other interesting stuff.
author: Sue G.

description:
My go to place in Chinatown.

You can read the other reviews to get an idea of what this place is like, the one thing people seem to leave out is their breakfast and afternoon specials.

Their breakfast menu is not translated into english but if you don't read Chinese you can figure it out by comparing it to their main menu.  It's mostly things like congee and sandwiches; I always get the congee.  It's a little cheaper than their regular menu price but it comes with a side of noodles!  Very filling breakfast.

Their happy hour is 3-5:30 and it's awesome!  First, the menu is in English!  Second, it's cheap!  All the items on the menu are $2.50!  You can get a bowl of noodles with beef stew for only $2.50!  There are things like congee, noodle soups, chicken wings, and other stuff on the menu, seriously good food and very inexpensive.  They also have plates of stuff out on the table; just grab whatever plate you want and eat!  Here you get things like roast pork (one of my favorites), fried rice, chicken wings, and other stuff.

My only complaint is the lack of chicken feet, I love chicken feet and they don't have them. : (
author: D D.

description:
I'm so hungry I can eat a whole pig right now! A whole suckling pig. Roasted over an open flame. Crispy glistening skin, lean tender meat. Crunch, crunch, crunch. Wow! 

Those of you who are pig lovers, you know what I'm talking about. Yee's will deliver the best damn roasted pig on the planet. Is that my appetite talking or can it be true. It doesn't matter because I'm sitting in Las Vegas, starving, and reminiscing of my roasted pork at Yee's Restaurant. 

No one does it better when it comes to roasting a pig to perfection. If you over cook, the skin gets tough and the meat is dry. If you under cook the skin and fat gets chewy. But if you do it perfect like Yee's, you will stuff yourself with so much meat you will oink.
author: My T.

description: I thought that this place was worth a try....but I was wrong. All I wanted was to try out a new place for cheap lunch. Did I get that? Oh I got cheap lunch alright. First off, when we first walk in...no one is even greeting us or leading us to a table. The workers there were just sitting there, watching us but not even saying anything. Then finally, this one guy comes up to us and finally serves us. My boyfriend ordered Beef with Broccoli and I ordered Beef with bell peppers in black bean sauce. It was $5 for each so I thought that it couldn't be that bad considering that there were many people in there. When we got the rice plates, it looked decent. Though looks can be deceiving! The meat was hot but the rice was warm. The sauce was very bland and it seemed like they just put soy sauce over the warm rice that they probably just microwaved. My boyfriend's plate was a bit better than mine...considering the fact that I found a bell pepper produce sticker still attached to the bell pepper piece that I almost ate. I was absolutely petrified because I don't know where that's been. Also, if there was a sticker on the bell pepper, maybe they didn't even wash the bell pepper before they cooked it! Anyways, I complained to the lady that was working there and she didn't really say much about it. She didn't even try to take responsibility for it at all or offer a refund. She tried to offer me another plate...but I didn't want to eat anymore of that garbage. I'll give her props for trying to offer me another plate though. It was a cheap lunch, but it was far beyond what I had expected...in a bad way! I'm never coming back here again. Worst experience ever.
author: Coco L.

description: Just a great job on the BBQ pork wonton noodle soup. Earlier I got it and the quality of pork was sub par, but every other time has been excellent quality so they get a few more stars from me.  For less than $6, this is a great bargain! I also enjoy getting an order of potstickers for less than $6. They serve it with a vinegar sauce that was surprising at first (it's a red sauce and most Americanized places serve potstickers with a sweet red sauce) but I'll admit the vinegar paired well with the potsticker filling
author: Ross I.

description:
Not the cleanest or fanciest restaurant I've been to, but I'd say it's right on par with the rest of Chinatown.  However; they definitely make up it with their food quality and prices!

The food was good, particularly the shoyu chicken.  Even better was the price- dinner for five people was just under $30!!  The portions were right, and we managed to stuff ourselves full without any leftovers.

Parking (or lack thereof) is another downside, but again, it's the same as any other restaurant in Chinatown.  Get lucky and find a spot on the street, or pay an arm and a leg at a nearby garage.
author: Chris Y.

description:
I was glad my friend and I happened upon this place after walking all the way through Chinatown! The ducks hanging by the window were a draw since I was looking for legit Chinese food.

I ordered the roasted duck, which was super tender and juicy, while also being nice and crisp on the outside. My friend ordered beef & broccoli that was tender as well. We shared the hot & sour soup and had leftovers to take home. I think we ended up paying around $10 each + tip.
author: Beth P.

description:
Yee's = Oh Em Gee!


You tell me... What's better than:
--------------------------------------------

* Massive, generous portions?

* Amazingly low Chinatown prices (per dish)?

* Extra extra friendly service?

* A comforting/warm interior atmosphere?

* Free yummy hot tea?

* A menu w/ lots of variety (& seafood!)?

* Some of the best tasting food you've ever had???

The Answer = Nothing!!!!


Go to Yee's the next time you're in C-Town...
Unless you hate food, uh, you won't regret it!

^_^
author: Kai S.

description:
One of my go to after noon tee place. The after noon tea menu here is $2.5 for food and ~$1.5 for drinks (not sure on drinks) The food is prepared very quickly. 

My favorite is always the Porkchop noodle (you can choose from many different kinds of noodle) 
Salt and pepper wings are great too!
author: Frederick A.

description: My son had the deep fried flounder, my Uncle the beef chow mien and I had soy chicken over white rice. All for under $20. Well worth it!
author: Marylou P.

description:
I had high hopes when I saw the roast duck hanging at the window. We were on our way to get Thai food, but decided to give this place a try. I wanted some legit canto food to bring me back to HK for a little bit, and the only legit dish we had was the roast duck. Between the two of us, we ordered:

Mongolian beef
Beef mi-fun with shrimp sauce
Stir-fry garlic big bean sprouts
Half a roast duck

The mongolian beef was pretty americanized. The mi-fun was too wet. The big bean sprouts were not in season and too oily. The roast duck was oily too, but it was good. We walked out satisfied only paying $35 for the meal.
author: Evangelline T.

description:
Oops wrong place
Do love the duck n pork and old Chinese people that clam our in and out
author: Sara N.

description:
What can I say...awesome!  They had an interesting 'to-go' sale going on in the late afternoon when I arrived. (I'm on East Coast time).  Wanted to buy it all...but took a table instead.

I went to order soup, Combo BBQ plate and greens, and "Kenny" told me that was enough for about 5 people...so I said, "Please, just feed me".  I received this "Jethro" bowl of soup with about 8 won-tons, a bunch of Chinese greens, and about 8-9 slices each of pork Char-siu and Roast Duck.  AWESOME!!!

Wait...it gets better - total $6.50!!!  Considering I spent $70 on lunch at Swan, I guess it evens out...I think Chinatown ROCKS!
author: Don M.

description:
Cheap prices
Btw, this review is NOT based on their bbq
We ordered chicken item and beef item and they somehow tasted very.... Rubbery like there was no real meat. After reading about how Chinese have synthetically made food including eggs, I really dont know what to say.... Prices are cheap but I think I could see why... But portions are big and the staff there do speak English

With wealth of Chinese options available nearby, will not be returning here.
author: Christina P.

description: This restaurant is a favorite of my aunt & uncle that live in the area.  This restaurant seems very affordable if I would venture a guess I think it was about $50-$60 to feed 4 people.  We had the tea, white rice, a clear soup, as well as 2 types of fish (one whole the other might have been steamed), we also had duck, roast pork, and chicken.  The food was good.  One thing to note is that the chicken and duck still had all the bones in it.  I think this is traditionally how it is served, but for me I can not try enjoy the meat trying to avoid all of the little bones.
author: Kris G.

description:
A friend and i go out a couple times a week and try new spots. We were heading for clay pots, but ran across Yee's on Grant and took a look at the butchers table, watching them cut up the fresh killed goose, ducks and pork.. After watching for a while we asked the price of each and it was really low so thought we'd give it a shot.

Goose over rice: $7
Complete wok seared fish:   $7
Chinese greens (bok choy)  $6

Pricing was great, service was on the spot, and food was tasty with non-heavy sauces. Mustard is freshly made but i couldn't tell if the condiments were on the table for a day or a year. I realized while i was sitting there that this was it felt a bit like a cafeteria with servers (or so it seemed). They were cleaning out the large tea brewers at the end of the night so i have a feeling they keep it clean, but after looking at clean scores i know there are several violations (only one major). 

All and all a good experience.
author: Adam X.

description: Only place in chinatown that you can get whole roasted goose at 10:00am and roasted pig even earlier st 9:30am. Go there on Sunday morning and you can imagine Anthony bourdain there talking about pork for breakfast with the locals
author: Kenneth L.

description: Crispy and delicious Peking duck ( for two people) with steamed buns, scallions, gravy and watermelon for dessert for $13. So, am I coming back to eat here? Yes!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
If we want a satisfying home styled meal, this place doesn't disappoint.  We come back over and over again for their 3 ala carte dishes for $15.99.  The complimentary house soup is always piping hot and the kind that's good for the soul.  Each meal ends with a plate of sweet oranges so can you go wrong?  Best part?  Always have extras to take home so you are basically paying for 2-3 meals.  

Our recent visits, we had chayote w/ pork and white bean soup and hairy melon w/ pork and white bean.  Both were flavorful.

Entrees we had:
stir fry thin slices of lotus root with sweet peas, black fungus and preserved bacon that were mostly fat - flavorful but the fatty bacon was a major turn off

seafood tofu pot - chunks of cod, shrimps and squid stewed with crispy soft tofu - love the tofu but it was a little salty

chicken with ginger and scallion - love this dish, tender chicken and I really love the finely sliced ginger and scallion

bitter melon sparerib - soul food at its best - huge portion - the bitter melon is sliced correctly, the spareribs are tender

green bean w/ chopped dried shrimp and preserved radish - this was SO good!  the dried shrimp and preserved radish added so much flavor to the dish, it was addicting...

fried soft tofu w/ shredded pork and preserved mustard green - this is ALWAYS good - the tofu is great and the pork is always so tender
author: Gloria H.

description:
I would give this place 0 stars if I could.

I came here to pick up goose on several occasions.  My grandmother loves to eat goose and this is one of the few places that sells it.

Unfortunately, time and time again, they've always tried to pull a fast one on me by either attempting to sell me:

1) subpar (day old) goose 
2) giving me impertinent/surly attitude (insisting the goose is fresh when it clearly isn't- thanks for showing contempt by making a mockery of my intelligence)
3) refusing to sell me half a goose and insisting I buy the entire goose

I've also noticed that I am a victim of age discrimination as they treat their older customers nicer than their younger "unknowledgeable" counterparts.

After putting up with their wretched service repeatedly for my grandmother's sake, I refuse to allow myself to be treated this way again.  

I'll be damned if I step foot in this sorry excuse of a restaurant again.
author: Dorothy L.

description: Hard to tell from the outside, but this place is actually really good and inexpensive. Around $6 for a roast duck with fried rice is not bad at all! Food tasted great, portion was huge and you can see right in the kitchen where they prepare it.
author: Robert K.

description:
I love how they display their MEAT.  Tables and tables covered in small plates of MEAT.  BBQ pork, crispy pork skin, roasted duck, soy sauce chicken, chow fun, chow mein, duck feet, duck wings, fried chicken, duck gizzards and much more, all displayed, laid out for all to see.  Patrons ( picky chinese people^^) walk from table to table deciding which plate they'd like to take home.

I like the duck here.  The duck here (compared to san jose) are leaner and more meaty.  Duck in san jose have a higher fat content.  Whenever i bite into a piece of duck, grease would just drip from the corners of my mouth.  But the duck here are more lean but still delicious.  I bought two whole ducks for the road.  HEHE.Roasted duck in sf Chinatown are much cheaper than San Jose's =[ no fair.

I didn't like the BBQ pork here though, parts of it were dry.
author: Ronnie N.

description: Delicious food, amazing duck; really enjoyed our lunch here.  We will definitely return.
author: katinka p.

description: Do not eat here! The portion and price was ok but there is no taste to the food. I think they gave us old meat and it stinks! My soup was cold as well! It is a "never return" for me.
author: Tracy L.

description:
We stumbled across this restaurant and decided to take a chance. Their menu was extensive, service was friendly and efficient. We ordered 3 dishes for $16.99 (deep fried flounder, seafood with tofu hot pot and walnut & butter prawn) and egg flower soup. 
Our bill was $22 and we took home leftovers. I was very pleased. It was a delicious meal... maybe just stay away from the toilets, though and bring cash. No card accepted!
author: Joy J.

description:
People that knock this place dont know what they are talking about, and have no experience in judging a dining experience....The best food, in my travels are always in small and authentic places with no ambiance, and quite frankly, look a little shady....the focus is on food.  This place offers some good old school Cantonese style cooking at very good prices.....This is not a tourist restaurant, that is why there are so many local Chinese patrons inside - thats a good sign you freaking idiots! I havent been on Yelp in a while...reading some of your lame rookie reviews, I recall exactly why I dont read Yelp reviews...most of you are kids with no experience and no taste whatsoever....

This place has alot to offer at great rates...and yes the duck is good....one other thing....one of the little girls who rated this place said you cannot order if you cant read Chinese .....not true little one....the menu is very much in English as well. Of course, there may be some things not listed  in the menu...that is the case with most authentic Cantonese / Chinese restaurants such as this.....2 people can dine really well here for 20 bucks....amateur, chain restaurant,  chi chi slaves need not apply.
author: Gomerio G.

description: Amazing roast duck, roast pig, Mongolian beef, egg rolls etc.  Server was upbeat and nice, and the 24oz Tsingtaos are only $5.
author: David R.

description:
You walk by here and you wonder, "Is this a tourist place?"  It has a good location for tourists.  But then there's tons of Chinese in there, and the requisite fowl carcasses hanging so it can't be bad.  We just wanted a quick snack because we were starvin' Marvin, and this place is quite generous.  The food is cheap, they give you a big complimentary soup to share, which is perfect for the cold winter days, and the food is cheap... yeah that was worth mentioning again.

Overall the food is above average as Chinese food goes.  If you are a college student then 4 stars for sure.  Oh yeah, and the big plate of oranges were a nice finish.  I thought we got the good treatment because my friend spoke Chinese, but really they do that for everyone.
author: Bryan K.

description:
Let's see, I came here during the mid afternoon in search for something good cheap and authentic...after all everyone talks about food (in Chinatown and in the world in general.......) ........

I've never been served tea in a coffee mug before, and it looked as dark as coffee.  Maybe just because the mug was dark.

I ordered the combination pan fried noodles...wow large portion, lots of soy sauce-y taste, bonus pieces of octopus (buried on the bottom, didn't see it until the end when I packed the rest to go), cha sieu, regular chicken, fish pieces, and what else... well there were a lot of "combinations".  

Next time I should order duck or pork, I guess those are popular huh..
author: Christina G.

description:
"It's OK".  I miss what used to be here 'tho. Growing up in SF, it was the site of Ping Yuen, a bakery which sold yummy fluffy cakes filled with strawberries or mandarin oranges and whipped cream.  Spend a "hangin with GF" morning at the North Beach Festival which is a hop and skip  from this joint.  She says her uncle loves coming here for lunch, so I agreed to try it.  

Didn't get a chance to try their BB items but she told me their roast goose is good.  We shared a fish congee - a huge scalding hot bowl of porridge cooked just the way I like it with a generous amt of thick slivers of fish.  Also tried their house fried chow mein.  The noodles were crispy fried and topped with sauce, vegts, squid and meats.  Not bad either.

Service was adequate. They take your order, serve you and leave you alone until you ask for the bill.  The bathroom is into and past the kitchen. It beats using a port-0-potty but beware, it's pretty old, in need of remodeling and doesn't look that clean.  The meal came to about $15 for the 2 of us.
author: Ry T.

description:
they have some good deals here, which drew me in to try this restaurant.
the food i ordered wasnt tasty and left my craving for chinese food unsatisfied.
i felt the food was inconsistent; some were salty and some were bland tasting.
they also had a section for meats for cheap for people to grab themselves, but how long were they sitting there for?!

another thing that pulled me in was that they serve GOOSE! sadly, this place didn't make it tasty either.
author: Anita W.

description:
Whoa...I thought this was my best kept secret. Secret's out I guess. This is my favorite restaurant in SF Chinatown. My family originally used to go to the deli to buy the roast goose, which is actually surprisingly difficult to find, even in Chinatown. Then we discovered the 3 item (plus soup) for $15.99 deal. We always order the salt and pepper spareribs and the fried flounder. It's delicious and a bargain. 

You may notice that at around 3 or so, the restaurant starts to get relatively crowded, which is counterintuitive because 3 o'clock is between mealtimes. This is because at 3, the restaurant puts food from the deli (chow mein, bbq pork, chicken wings, etc.) on dishes. The plates are then placed on a table only to be quickly claimed by various customers. Why. you may ask? The plates are sold for ridiculously cheap prices. I'm talking China cheap, like $2 a plate. 

Join the frenzy but don't you dare get in between me and my wings. :P
author: Courtney C.

description: Great food, nice service! Locals eat here so quality is high and the price is right. I'll come back again
author: Karl M.

description:
The restaurant never really stood out for me until one day I checked the posted menu and saw one particular "rare" item: roast goose. Just the site of the item's name makes me think of being in Hong Kong. So I made a point of visiting the restaurant and ordering that item over rice (which at $7, is at least $2 higher than the other rice plates.

The roast goose didn't disappoint, and it came with a decent bowl of house soup. The service did greatly disappoint, however, because they sat me down and forgot about me. There was no menu or anything until I called out to somebody. At least he apologized. However, for that they get a reduced rating. If I go again and it improves, them I might raise it back up.
author: H K.

description: Closes at 9pm as we happen to make our way thru chinatown and stumbled into this restaurant after some bar hoping adventures. We ordered and with lighting quick reflex the food showed up on out table in less then 4 minutes. great Food will be back for sure!!!!
author: Peter B.

description:
I would say it's okay.  But definitely order some veggie dishes.  The veggies in SF are FRESH (i.e. bitter melons, ong-choy, pea sprouts, and many extremely Asian veggies).  The meats were okay, but not bad.  The seafood oddly cost more than our area.

Tip: If you see Chinese restaurants that puts out folks, rice in a bowl instead of rice in a covered pot, you're in the wrong "Chinese" restaurant.

Coming from the LA county from the city of Alhambra, CA, I'm surprised there aren't the grading system in restaurants, eateries, markets, and shops that carry foods.
author: LilMiss S.

description: The suckling pig banquet dinner is still really good.  We did complain about the incident reported here in 2010.  It has not happened again (4 pig dinners, later!).   Redeemed!
author: Debbie T.

description: Abundant tasty food - inside a busy establishment. The menu seemed inexpensive (and it was) and the food was tasty and plentiful for the price. We had the Snow Peas and Prawns, the Kung Pow Chicken, Spring Rolls and Shrimp Fried rice - and soon realized that we had enough food for at least 4 HUNGRY people.  Good value and would go again to try other items.
author: Tim H.

description: This place rocks. Stumbled upon it during my most recent trip to SF. Good, cheap  authentic chinese food and excellent service. Order the shredded pork wonton noodle soup, you won't regret it. Fast and efficient service. I will definitely return someday.
author: Katie E.

description:
Excellent food.  We tried the pot stickers, several noodle dishes, a fresh fish and veggie dish, a noodle soup with duck and egg rolls. For seven people, each with their own dish, one beer and a soda. Incredibly the bill came out to $40!!!  
Really truly Chinatown atmosphere. I swear the Chinese mafia sat at a table next to us. They ordered a fish. The cook came out with one huge fish, wiggling in a net. REALLY fresh!  

Only thing that was a bit of a strange thing was they had ducks hanging in the window and a woman constantly zapping the flies with a sort of electrified handball racket thing. I was grossed out and fascinated at the same time. Totally recommend. We had so much left over for lunch the next day too.
author: Roxanne D.

description:
What a deal! 3 entrees for $15.99. We added a vegetable dish and total came out to be $22. Fed three people with enough to spare.

We had salt and pepper spare ribs, honey walnut prawns, mongolian beef, and a mixed vegetables plate.  Food was delicious and a great value.  I'll be back!
author: Linda P.

description:
Perfect for what it is: fast, cheap, filling Chinese food.

I got vegetable chow mein noodles and some hot tea: $5. Plus, there's enough for another entire serving (cold, leftover noodles are very satisfying, if you didn't already know. Especially at 2am!)

I went here with my Chinese coworker and I think we got good treatment because she spoke to them in Cantonese. Not that they were openly discriminating against non-Asian folk, but I'm just sayin'...our tea came out *very* fast.
author: Hannah L.

description:
Had planned on coming here the other day and after standing inside for a minute, decided to eat some where else. We were waiting to be seated and was ignored. 

The place wasn't that clean for a place trying to attract tourist. It had this smell of intestines being cleaned in the back.
author: M C.

description: Food came out in less than 10 minutes, u can stop in as early as 9a for somethin to eat and it's as authentic china as u can get with even the roast ducks in the window.
author: Jo A.

description: Went there with three other persons. We shared a soup with duck, a rice dish with pork and shrimp sauce, a rice dish with beef and fried noodles with shrimps. Everything was delicious, service was very friendly and quick and above all the price was very competitive (ca. 50 USD including tip). I had the impression we got pretty authentic chinese food. The interior is not very fancy, if you want that, go somewhere else. But if you want to experience great chinese food you won't be disappointed.
author: Oliver M.

description:
Holy dang!  I heart this place a lot.  This is now a pit stop when I am in SF.

I can order a hefty load of food and pay under 35 bucks!  Cheap and delicious is what we dubbed this place.  I am not Chinese (nor are my dinning partners, typically) so when we get here we look around and order a dish that is not on the menu that our neighbor had order (right?  wouldn't you want something the table next to you is eating?).  What's good: chowfun, hk chowmien, duck (but you can't really mess that up), fish dishes, and mix veggies.

The folks here speaks only Cantonese to me and my party every time we go!  So use hand gestures and smile a lot of you want fast and nice service.  I like how the waitress will even come over to laugh with us (or  laugh at us laughing).

I can't wait to head back.  Yummy.  (Oh, one note: bathroom is scary).
author: MSee Y.

description:
One of my grandma's favorite joints, but you have to know what to order.  This is not a sweet and sour pork with eggroll joint.  

Their won ton is really good (which I have found is surprisingly hard to fine, even in Chinatown).  I also really like their beef with bittermelon, and their hom yee fried rice.  They also have some well-done down-home dishes like pork hash (with hom yee, why not!). 

Pretty fast for take-out too, so if you don't want the whole experience of eating at a Chinatown hole-in-the-wall, you can still have their tasty food in the comfort of your own home. 

Also, they have this special menu with some plentiful selections --  three dishes for like $16 or something crazy like that.  Comes with house soup too, which is savory broth that has been simmering a long time with some little bits of stuff in it (whatever they feel like at the moment, e.g., some beef, wintermelon, lotus root, etc.).
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
Their 3 for $15.99 is an all right deal.  If you order more than three, you get some broth/soup to go with your meal.  The price is pretty cheap, but the food is super bland and plain.  It's a good place to go if you just need something quick to fill your belly, but look elsewhere if you want a delicious meal.

I was disappointed by the flavor the first time but I gave it a second chance.  My second trip, I decided to order different items on the menu and I was still disappointed by the food.  The meal size is decent and the service is pretty fast, however the food was incredibly bland.  I must be spoiled by my mom's delicious home cooking.
author: A V.

description: We got the cooked dishes, rather than the bbq, which was a big mistake. The fish was tough and overlooked, shrimp was also tough and not how seafood should taste, and the pork ribs were flavorless. Would only recommend/ come back for BBQ and not anything from the kitchen.
author: Ming Z.

description:
I would love to give it Four stars but this place is so dirty! Cramping 13 ppl in one of their largest tables was the least uncomfortable, especially with unstable-like chairs! 

I come here for family gatherings because the price is very reasonable and we have a family friend here whom is very accomadating and friendly whenever we're there.

Came here three times in total, two out of three times the food is delicious. Dishes to recommend: Sweet Spare Ribs "Ging doe Gwut", Sturgeon fish cooked into two dishes, one mixed with veggies, and the other one mixed with the fish bones & tofu and mushroom, Spinach with egg, Honey Walnut Prawns, Stir Fried Clams ( big sized clams full of flavor), Garlic Pea Sprouts, Braised Tofu with Veggies, Bitter melon with spareribs (beware, bitter melon is bitter...if you like that type of vegetable, you will appreciate the bitterness) 

Dishes to pass on: Beef Pan-fried noodle (beef were bland, noodles were crunchy good though), Fried pork intestine ( some pieces seemed raw & was not crunchy like other places), the Cold Steamed Chicken from the front ( dry, no flavor, and was served to us raw before)

Unfortunately whenever we eat here for dinner, the roasted pork is either "old" or out so we didn't get a chance to try.

Unlimited Rice! not served per bowls.
author: Shirley A.

description: I remember coming to this place every once in awhile with my family when I was younger. Haven't been here in awhile because my grandparents moved closer to us but we did stop by today for a late lunch after taking my grandma to her appointments around the corner. Not much has changed. The food is still legit. Great Chinese bbq/deli up front. Big portions and its cheap! We ordered seafood chow mein, beef chow fun with gravy and westlake style jook. Everybody left full and we still had leftovers. Where else can you get lunch for 4 including tip for $18 and change?
author: Sarah L.

description: Not special or anything, just plain humble blue collar Hong Kong style Chinese food. It is tasty and filling, but not spectacular or even special in any way, but then again, that's part of the appeal of this place. This is a good place to have an inexpensive lunch in the city, portions are big, food is 3 stars, but value is 4 stars. I wish I cold give half stars.
author: Winston W.

description: Soul food - Chinese style. Can't beat the prices. When you want to get real, eat here. Roast duck, ese.
author: André C.

description: Three items for $16.99 means very good comfort food.  nothing fancy.  soup is free.  rice is extra.  good comfort food.  good company and you have all the right ingredients for a great meal
author: Bill L.

description:
Yum! Chinese food after a long day walking around at the Chocolate Festival. This is a place my boyfriend used to frequent when he lived in SF and I was really craving some sort of noodle soup for cheap. We walked in and were greeted right away and given a table. Our waiter was real nice and when my boyfriend asked in one dish came with vegetables (which it didn't) he told the cooks to put bok choy in it for us! Sweet jeebies! 

We ordered a noodle soup with beef, some pork jook, and lai fun with bok choy. 

Noodle soup with beef: Delicious. The noodles were glass noodles but still tasty. The meat had nice tendons attached, which always give great flavor. It was my 2nd favorite dish.

Pork Jook with preserved egg: The preserved egg gives the jook a lot of tastiness but I don't eat the egg itself, that's for my boyfriend. it was a bit thick for a jook, but still tasty. The pork was salty (in a good way) and fell apart in the jook. NOM! I loved this dish. It was so filling and tasty! MY favorite dish of the night.

Lai Fun: This was alright. It was my first time trying lai fun and it reminded me of chow mein that was chopped crudely and covered in soy sauce. It was tasty, yes, but it was hard to eat with chopsticks. I'd probably avoid getting it next time I come. Kudos for the bok choy, which was clean and really absorbed the flavor of the noodles and sauce.
author: squishy b.

description:
My boyfriend and I spent a long weekend in San Francisco and on the top of our to-do list was to go to a great little hole-in-the wall Chinese restaurant in Chinatown,  We found Yee's and were very hopeful considering it looked like it catered to a lot of locals. Inside was very simple and kinda dirty.  We were seated right away and everything sounded great on the menu. We were really bummed when the waiter came around to take our order and we were told that almost everything we were planning on getting was sold out or they no longer made it.  No big deal, we just ordered the Mongolian beef, pig intestines, half of a duck, and shrimp fried rice. 

We got our food very quickly, I don't even think it was 3 minutes since we had ordered.  The Mongolian beef and shrimp fried rice left much to be desired.  Both dishes had absolutely no flavor, which surprised me.  I din't try the pig intestine or the duck (those were my bf's dishes), but he said he's had better.  

Overall it was a pretty disappointing, but maybe we just came on an off-night.
author: Sarah C.

description: The best place to get duck in Chinatown.  The roast duck is tender and delicious. The won ton soup is to die for, a large portion that can be shared between two people.  Fried rice is good and not greasy.  Very reasonable prices.  Quick service.  Serves beer and wine.  Casual, family style.
author: Lauren M.

description: I am not a big fan of Chinese restaurants in general.  When I crave Chinese food, I prefer the great cooking of my parents.  But there are some occasions that we have to go out to eat and I have long ago, given up on trying new places with my parents.  They want cheap, big portions and fast service (aka...Chinese Food).  That is where Yee's come in.  They are close to home, they are well staffed and never short handed, they have good prices, and they have good portions.
author: Stella C.

description:
My buddy and I strolled into Yee's restaurant on a whim. First noticeable thing is all the dirty, old Chinese men eating all over the restaurant. 

We sat down and everything on the menu was pretty much under $5. We ended up getting two bowls of wonton soup and they were each like $4. Not a bad deal. We didn't specify wonton noodle soup in one of them, and when we consulted the waitress, she advised us to just order another side of noodles instead because they would take some of the wontons out. thanks for the tip!

the food was pretty good. i think everyone else has it right: what you see and pay for is what you get. that goes for the service too. i swear i saw our server pick his nose on the way out of the kitchen. gross. i'm a big germaphobe. and that is not okay to me.

we ordered another chicken, boiled, and the check came out to be $18. kinda surprisingly pricey, but i think it was because of the chicken which we ended up taking home anyway. 

anyway, i would definitely stop by for a quick meal if i needed a meal in the city. not a bad deal if the server's boogers don't land in my meal
author: stacy c.

description:
Yee's Restaurant is a good value Chinese dining experience.  Saw outside their posted menu three items for USD 15.99.  There is a on display food items to go.  We got seated inside and given menus but not the one we saw outside.  I asked about the menu with three dishes for USD 15.99.  Another menu was brought to us with that offer.  We ordered a roasted pigeon, tofu with preserved vegetables, and a fish, but instead of deep fried on the menu, the waiter suggested I could order it steamed with ginger and scallions instead.  The fish was great, the pigeon was too salty, the tofu was very delicate and the preserved vegetables on it way too salty.

We tried coming here another time but they said they were closed even though there was still another twenty minutes before their stated closing time of 9pm, need to be seated at least half an hour before their stated closing time from that experience.
author: George L.

description: The three choices for $16.99 can't beat that. Peking spareribs, fried flounder and salt and pepper wing goooood stuff. House rice was disapointing. The place was packed. The service was ok, I seen the waiters getting messed up lol good times good times.
author: Sothary C.

description:
This place has CHEAP Chinese food. For a table of 6 with 6 plates, dinner with tax came out to $50! They also have this special menu for 3 items on the list for $16.
----------------------------------------
Hot and Sour soup- 3.5 stars. It was interesting the stuff they put in here. I've never had this soup with raddish before. It actually tasted pretty good and it was the perfect spicy/sour ratio.

BBQ pork- 3.5 stars. Yum.

Roasted pork- 4.5 stars. The best dish of the entire meal. Who can resist that fatty, crunchy, fried pig skin? Mmmmmm.

Walnut shrimp- 1 star. This was horrible IMO. It had too much mayonnaise and the shrimp tasted FISHY. YUCK.

Salt and pepper fried chicken- 2 stars. It tasted ok, but a little dry. I've had better chicken wings.

Clams with black bean sauce- 3 stars. Comparable to other places, but still tastes a little fishy to me. On the plus side, the clams seemed to be on steriods.
------------------------------------------
And it IS a Chinese restaurant so service is a little spotty. The waiter was nice enough though and even suggested 1.5 bowls of soup for the whole table when we asked if one was enough. That was a first! And instead of fortune cookies, they give out sweet, tastes like liquid sugar watermelon! YUM.
-----
Oh, and CASH only!
author: Ling H.

description: When I saw this place is full of local Chinese I know this must be a very original Hong Kong restaurant. Most of the customers here speak Cantonese that makes me feel I was eating food somewhere at HK. I love it! The Roast duck and ginger fried seafood tastes great. They serve free fruits for you as dessert when you finished your meal. The price is so reasonable! However, be aware of the "a little bit dirty" environment.
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Came here twice. My overall rating? THIS PLACE SUCKS. 
If I were you, I'd go anywhere but here. 

The first time, the food was LUKE WARM. The only thing that was hot was the tea. The floors are hella sticky too. 

The 2nd time, we got some shitty service. I swear though the food here is either stir fried or deep fried and nothing else. The waiters totally ignored us, and when we asked for a small box, they give you this "we hate our own Asian kind" look, they ignored us. We left without paying them a tip. 

Yee's service, food and atmosphere SUCKS. The only reason their open is because its on Broadway and Grant, right smack in the middle of the tourist area. I feel sorry for tourists who end up eating here, then see them dart for a bathroom. 

Lastly 3 out of 5 of my friends got sick here. They had upset stomach for a week.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
2009-12-25

Been there many times, place is bad and really bad... as usual, but what makes it really bad this time around is this

1. I ordered a roast goose with rice, usually it comes as leg quarter and believe or not it come just the "drumstick" this time around and it is $7 now... price increase

2. Food volume seems to be decreasing much more than before.

It was really a good budget restaurant before, but makes no mistake, this time they really screw one loyal customer....
author: Wils G.

description:
Came here with my dad, walking through on our way to the waterfront touristy stuff. We hadn't looked up anywhere to eat and were looking in the windows of places, trying to decide, when my dad was about to give up and just buy a piece of fruit. I laid eyes on Yee's and decided we would go there. 

It looked full of locals, so we figured it must be pretty good. Opened the menu and were very pleased with the prices. My dad had the "Vegetarian," which included seaweed, and he was pretty stoked about that.

I asked the waiter what the most popular thing was that people ordered, and he said the roasted meats, namely the duck, goose, pork. I ordered the duck with rice, and there was not quite enough rice, but the duck was excellent (though very fatty - I got a bit of a stomach ache later on. Think Whitecastle's sliders...yeah). I forgot to ask whether they used MSG, but I couldn't taste any, and I didn't get that weird sleepy feeling afterward that MSG gives me.

Unlimited tea, though I guess pretty typical, was a nice treat on a long day of walking.

I'd recommend it if you'd like a low-cost Chinatown lunch to offset the cost of those pricey Ghiradelli ice cream treats and boat rides around the bay. My dad and I certainly found our Yee's experience to be satisfying.
author: Lisa M.

description:
We waited in line for about half an hour granted that it was 7pm on a Saturday night, nonetheless during Mother's Day weekend. It's definitely a place where you have to stand your ground and make sure that you get your table. People aren't going to be nice to you here.

We ordered the $138 dinner special and the food was AMAZING! Everything came in big quantities and we had 5 take home boxes after the night was over. I must say that it was the most I've eaten in a very long time.

The staff was excellent too, catering to whatever we needed even though it was extremely busy in the restaurant. I'm giving it five stars for the food and the service.
author: Teresa N.

description:
All around the world, there are apparently multiple ways to say something along the lines of

"Ehhhh, it was just alright" 

or 

"Well it wasn't earth shattering (referring to food or sex, or food porn for that matter), but it wasn't like it made me cry afterewards, I don't need a tissue, dear."

In Cantonese one might say

"Ma Ma Dei" (which is just bordering a bit on the bad side) or "ma ma fu fu" (with a slight emphasis on clumsiness and lack of care or putting one's heart into improving the outcome)

In Mandarin, the equivalent would be "ma ma hu hu"

And in French from what I remember, it's "comme ci, comme ca" (pronounced comme si, comme sa) which sounds a lot more snotty.

Yee's is one of those neighborhood type eats, no nonsense. The Chinese name is pronounced Mun Jai Gei Siu Lap Cha Chaan Teng. First three characters is like "Little Mun's" (or "Mun-chan" in Japanese speak). Siu Lap referring to the fact that this place specializes in Cantonese style ROASTIES. Cha Chaan Teng is a Hong Kong style cafe that typically serves a mish mash of Cantonese Chinese and HK style western. 

So once again, a generic name like Yee's Restaurant doesn't tell you anything else.

From what I remember about Yee's, they don't have a HK style western side to their menu, and perhaps the substitute to that is roasties.  I can't remember if they have HK milk tea and if they did, whether it was worth the bother.

So if you're here to cure hunger pains, prefer something that's good value (i.e. half decent to decent portions but not sextacular refinement) then Little Mun's will roast and pork you in the stomach.

Congee was not earth shattering here, just hit the spot, but didn't produce those orgasms like at Hing Lung (which they are more well known for orgasmic creamy congee that takes your high to the clouds).

If this place were in the South Bay or Peninsula, for sure it would rate a lot higher.
author: Ken K.

description: Saw this on Shirley Fong-Torres's website; it was one of many restaurants she took one of her tour groups to and well no frills, it makes up for it in the low prices, friendly but brisk service, and simple Cantonese food.  The pot stickers are crispy golden with a wonderful ground pork, cabbage, and ginger filling; perfect with the rice vinegar.  The beef ly fun is to die for with tender marinaded beef and light ly fun with that golden wok taste.  The kung pao chicken is tender with mushrooms, peppers, celery, carrots, and peanuts in a chili sauce that packs a bit of spice but not like at a Szechwan restaurant as this is a Cantonese restaurant.  I would definitely come back.  So, for excellent simple Cantonese food at low prices with brisk but nice service in a friendly no frills atmosphere, Yee's cannot beat beat.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description: This place is Chinatown cheap!!  You can't beat it.  At first i didn't get what was going on.  Plates were being placed on a table, and you just get what you want.  Each plate is 2.60!  - they had plates of chicken, fried rice, noodles, etc.  All the usual chinese foods.  There's no ambiance here - it's like a cafeteria but if you are craving chinese food, and in the neighborhood, with only a few dollars in your pocket, you will eat well here.
author: Bebe W.

description:
My friends and family all agree on this: Most Chinese people will not opt to eat Chinese food in Chinatown when they are in San Francisco... especially if the restaurant in question is on Grant Ave. We never, ever eat on Grant Ave. since almost every single store on it caters to tourists (okay, so maybe not the live poultry shop, but...). 

I came here with coworkers while I was working remotely the other day, and the food was definitely just okay to sub-par. The beef chao fun was really greasy, the sweet and sour pork heavy on the cornstarch, and the pot stickers pretty unremarkable, especially in comparison to the ones I love in New York. The beef stew, a dish that I chose, was a good dish, but it was still a little oily. 

It also didn't help that the bathroom was flooded and I had to nearly swim to get to the toilet. Not good.
author: Yvonne W.

description:
Remember Chinatown is not where you want to be for great Chinese food..........but when in Rome..............

This place is good..............just don't order the food that is on display.  They have your basic foods out there.  Chicken, pork, goose, duck, intestines...........etc.  Order food that the chef have to make to order.

Salt and pepper chicken wings with extra peppers

Salt and pepper spare ribs

Crispy fried chicken

Any of the vegetables of the day

I even had curry chicken today and it was great.

Price is very reasonable...............will always come back here.  

I actually walked by on Jackson St. and they have this special for 5.95 for all you can eat dim sum.  Sounds very scary and looked very interesting.  It is alluring enough where you will say.............sure..........why not.....  6 dollars for all you can eat.  hahahaha.  
I need to get a dozen shots of grey goose at Mr bings or Reds before I will eat over here.  You never know.............i just might.
author: jason g.

description:
Wow, I'm truly surprised by such a high star rating. 

Every time I've been there (it's been awhile since the last time I went, and for good reason too), I ALWAYS end up with a stomach ache.. ALWAYS. I don't know if it's me or what. I just have bad experience with this place. The food was decent for Chinatown, but it's the after effects that are the reasons that I'm giving such a low star count.

Even though my bad experiences with this place happened awhile back (at least 3 years), it has placed a long-lasting impression on me. I'm sorry, I cannot in MY right mind come back ever again. I sincerely hope this restaurant has changed a lot since I last went.
author: Sam W.

description: Cheap, but the duck was not that great.  Upset my stomach and my son wasn't well the next day.  It wasn't food poisoning, but it wasn't pleasant either!
author: Kristin Z.

description:
I had the best salt and pepper fried chicken wings I have ever had here. The Colonel Harland Sanders should run and hide because his do not compare. 

There were noodles on the seats, a roasted pig on the counter, Budweiser served out of the can, and millions of people crowded into this restaurant and I loved every minute of it. Although I found the plastic chop sticks nearly impossible to use (compared to the wood ones) I struggled through it and finally just started eating the delicious pot-stickers, egg rolls, and chicken wings with my hands. 

The food is so incredibly cheap. If you have a choice, which I am sure you won't, try to sit by the butcher. You see tons of chickens, ducks, and meat being chopped and served. At one point I saw a chicken head, beak and all, be chopped and I swear we made eye contact. It was quite an experience. 

We left with tons of leftovers and full bellies. It was just $30 for three of us to eat a ton! Now that I know they have take-out I may be back for those wings mid-week. The window display says it all... authentic and good!
author: Natalie N.

description:
Every time I come to SF via BART we walk here and grub!
Cheap but good eats and their economy plates are filling. 
Inside they usually have a couple of large tables with plates of roasted, fried and other items you can just grab and bring to your table.
author: Beezy G.

description:
Passed by Yee and saw the perfectly glazed roast duck screaming my name telling me to eat her....

How can I resist?

So I sat down with my coworker, we both ordered the irresistable-looking roast duck with rice noodle soup.  OMG, generous portion of duck and bouncy rice noodle in nice tasty broth.  The best duck noodle soup I had in a LONG while.

And the best part is?  Including tax, it was only $5.50....  Wow...
author: Gigi T.

description: This is your typical, delicious Chinese restaurant. I was disappointed though because they didn't have any roasted duck left - seriously disappointing. But everything else was delicious and good prices.
author: Diana H.

description:
Yee Yee!! :)   I am giddy from my visit here for dinner. Unsure of what to pick, we decided to go with Yee's ...boy was it a wise choice! 

The food: excellent.  All very flavorful and chinese greasiness at its best! The meal consisted of Salt & Pepper chicken wings (VERY flavorful), Hong Kong Style Chow Mein, Eggrolls, Potstickers, Broccoli Beef, & of course rice. All recommended plates that were full of flavor. And best of it, good portions for a reasonable price. The 3 of us engorged in all this food for merely $30. WOW.    

Most exciting umm okay maybe weird: Pigeon. I was actually a bit disgusted considering I see like swarm of them dirtifying their selves on the street daily. I just hope they're not finding these birds on the street! I'm too much of a wuss to try that out. 

Environment was very busy. Crowded, and full of many chinese families, which was good to see! All them hanging out, drinking Budweisers out of cans, whole pigs chillin, & whole chickens hanging on skewers..occasionally the butcher comin around to chop em up. Cleanliness....well it's an Asian restaurant, it's not the cleanest, but not the dirtiest! 

I definitely had fun here. The service was nothing to complain about and they were pretty nice & served us fairly quickly. I'll be back for more chicken wing action...and maybe suck it up and try one of those pigeons......  

just maybe....
author: Catherine O.

description: My dad cooked all his life for a living in Hong Kong and the Bay Area, and we always come here whenever we go out for dinner - so much that the staff knows them! Enough said ;)
author: Lois W.

description: Went there on a whim one Sunday evening, when most other restaurants and bakeries were closed. They had a good selection of entrees on their 3 for $15.99 menu. The portions were very generous for the price that we paid, and the service was quick. Our order of pigeon meat with sugar snap peas, beef with Chinese broccoli, and seafood tofu hot pot came with a bowl of yellow bean soup. To no surprise, they charged us extra for steamed white rice, but the meal still came out to be just $22 including tax + tip, and we had plenty of leftovers!
author: Tina C.

description: NOT GOOD. I feel like I would get sick from the food -- SOOOOO much oil!!!!! GROSS CHINESE FOOD. I had the peking duck with rice. EEEHHH... anyway not coming back here again.
author: Vera W.

description: Very VERY authentic. Probably a bit too authentic for my taste and I'm a fairly adventurous eater. The roast duck was phenomenal but the beef was mushy, slimy and fatty. Steer clear of pork & beef. Pot stickers were good and doughy.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Food - 4
Service - 3.5
Ambience - 3

On a rare warm San Francisco night, my husband and I  ventured forth to show his 20 year-old cousin around the City (he had just moved up here for school). We tried to go to R&G Lounge, where I was told that they were "full" when I inquired how long the wait would be. Hmph ...

So, onward we pushed with our empty stomachs for some din-din. Lucky for us, the cuz had a trick up his sleeve and took us to Yee's Restaurant. After getting over the initial shame of letting him down and having to rely on a kid who had only been in the City a mere 4 days to show US around ... I stepped boldly into Yee's with a skeptical mind. After all, what did a 20-year old Caucasian boy know about good Chinese food, right?!

Well, I could not be more proud of him! Yee's is a GREAT family restaurant with flavorful, authentic food at incredible prices. If you go there, you MUST have an open mind about the service & decor - neither of which is anything to write home about. Their seating system, or lack thereof, can be a bit frustrating as it basically consists of standing around waiting for a table to open and hoping that the staff remembers you were here before the people next to you. The chairs & tables receive the cursory wipe down after each patron leaves.

BUT if you can see past these two elements, you are in for a treat. We dined on the 3 for $15.99 dinner menu. The cuz really wanted the char siu, which was good - a little fatty but cooked perfectly so that it wasn't dry. We also had the mixed seafood with vegetables dish - squid (again, cooked perfectly and not chewy), shrimp & bok choy - fresh & flavorful. The final dish was the black pepper chicken (or was it pork?). Regardless, it was DEE-LISH. Very peppery.

Add to that incredible value, the free soup at the start of the meal (any place that will include the chicken head in the soup means serious business, I say) and free watermelon at the end of the meal (who needs fortune cookies?!), and you've got yourself one heck of a meal for under $20.
author: Lynn H.

description: I love this place for lunch. Perhaps it's the equivalent of an HK greasy spoon or chopstick but the roast duck and assorted canto dishes are awesome. Service is fast especially if you know what you want. If you use the restroom, you have to go through the rest of the building, and um, don't look around too much in the back. hahahaha.
author: Miguel L.

description:
So I went to SF about 2 months ago with my girlfriends and Jamie D. highly suggested this restaurant.  I was sooo darn hungry that night and I remembered ordering my all time favorite, bittermelon cooked with black bean sauced spareribs.  IT was YUMMM!!  The next day, my family went to the same restaurant too!  From what I hear from my aunt, there were actually commercials in Hong Kong promoting this restaurant.  I guess word gets around.  The plate sizes are HUGE and it's a great deal for the price that you pay.  I believe it's cheaper than the restaurants in Monterey Park.  

True, this is not a place you take on a first date because there's no ambiance here whatsoever.
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
I've been walking by Yee's several times a day for several months so I finally stopped in... Nothing really that special. The food was cheap but overall just mediocre.

I doubt I'll go back.
author: Thel D.

description:
DO WANT!

This place is extremely overcrowded, which means you have to fight for your food like a gladiator. Fortunately, it's worth it - their roasted/bbq meats are delicious. Although the duck wasn't torched enough, so it had a little too much fat left on it. Prices are dirt cheap: for under $5 I can get a big ass plate of bbq meat and rice. They also have great garlic bok choy - very tender and delicious broth.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Yee's is a great spot for cheap Chinese food in Chinatown.  I took a Chinese friend who was visiting the city and she felt that the place was very good.  She commented on the won ton soup, which I have to agree is especially good here.

I am not a big fan of the ducks and what not hanging in the window, but if you can get over that, the food is very flavorful.  The portions are also large for the price.  The atmosphere isn't worthy of 4 stars, but who cares if the food is good and cheap, right?  Personally, I find this restaurant to be very entertaining.
author: Ryan W.

description:
It's where to go for cheap-but-good Chinese. They have a $5 menu that has tons of great dishes; I got a pan-fried fish here that would cost $10 anywhere else. When I'm feeling too lazy to cook in the winter I come  for a massive container of jook that serves as both dinner and the next day's lunch. 

The decor here is nothing to brag about. They've got flimsy tables and duct tape on the chairs, but with such good value for the food, I can't complain.
author: Lorenzo M.

description: Good food,great price,moody service and hard to find parking but it"s worth it.
author: jose m.

description: Can we give this place a a negative star. Restaurant maybe less than half full. Early to lunch. Seated and served tea. Waiter took time to get order. Sat and sat and sat and watched everyone else who came later got their food. We waited patiently for close to half hour before flagging the waiter. Waiter mumbled that we were to wait (even longer). We upped and left.
author: Rrr X.

description: Superior won tons in the won ton soup with perfectly cooked greens. Not-the-best-quality-but-not-terrible beef in the otherwise delicious beef with bitter melon. In short, everyday delicious Cantonese food the way it's supposed to be. Yum.
author: Jane M.

description: Are you in Chinatown and wanting cheap excellent Chinese Food , then this place is it. It has a wide selection of seafood with mixed Chinese BBQ such as roast duck char su (BBQ pork) roasted pork and a good selection of seafood. One fault it has is the specials are in Chinese and there is a hidden menu that has 3 items for 16 bucks ( you can add extra dishes on that menu for just 6 bucks more) which comes with soup, rice is optional at 1 buck per person all you can cram in your mouth. I've taken many of my of friends here and it never fails to amaze the quality of the food for the price they charge. This place is cash only and if you get there by 830 they'll cook up your meal and close shop.
author: Jorm K.

description:
Well, I had to give 1 star somehow... the chicken was uncooked, bland, no salt and had a few drops of soy sauce...the chowmein was cold, half cooked and the chicken smelled... the fish curry had a few peices except there was no curry and humongous vegetable peices. At 3, they line up the left overs of the day for $2, which is a culinary suicide.

Dont even think about going here
author: Sav B.

description:
don't patronized this place, they are thieves.

here's our story, i drove my mom here after work to pick up some dinner to take home.  she decided to buy 1/2 of a duck last minute, they are the ones just hanging by the window.  it cost $6.50 for the 1/2 of the duck.  the man took the duck to chop up.  he does this behind a metal screen of some sort.  when my mom got home, she looked for her absolute favorite piece to eat, the shoulder and wing.  you guessed it, it was missing.  she bought 1/2 a duck, it was attached when the man took it behind the screen to chop.  why is it not in her box?  we hear about this a lot on the chinese radio station about other restaurants.  the workers steal a piece here and there and add up the pieces to put on a rice plate.  it's so dishonest of these people, give me what i paid for.  GIVE EVERYBODY WHAT THEY PAID FOR.
author: Jeanie L.

description:
Beef chow fun for $5?  

Beef chow fun portions large enough to feed two people?  

Beef chow fun large enough for two people for $5.  

Where do you get this?  At Yee's Restaurant.
author: Tim L.

description: This place offers pretty authentic Cantonese dishes. The mune is huge so you will definitely find something you like. The best deal for a group or family is the three dish plus rice option. You get to choose three dishes from a long menu for a extremely reasonable price and it comes with steamed rice. The portions are very generous and I always leave with leftovers. They also have a counter that sells cooked food and roast ducks and the sorts. If you go in late afternoon, they have discounted dishes lined up on the table. Whenever I don't feel like cooking dinner, I stop by there to see what's out. This is definitely not a tourist trap.
author: Alva L.

description:
i sort of have a love/hate relationship with yee's... the kind you have where, as a kid, your parents drag you here every week without fail, whether it's for breakfast, afternoon tea, or dinner. you get so used to their 3 dishes for $16 and set menus that it drives you nuts, but your parents still come here because it's a good value.

but tonight i was reminded of the perks of being regulars here: kind service and decent quality. tonight we ordered some special things for my mom's birthday, including:

- shrimp and fruit salad (special request) consisting of fresh shrimp, white peaches, asian pears, cantaloupe and lichee mixed with mayonnaise... you may think it's weird, but it's frickin' genius!
- deep fried quail... delectable, especially with a little squeeze of lemon
- mince squab in lettuce cups... usually you get maybe 8 nicely trimmed lettuce cups if you're lucky, but since we're regulars we nearly got a whole head!
- fresh stir fried fish with crispy bones... very nicely done with crunchy deep fried fins to nibble on
- stir fried yam leaves with bamboo pith... delicious! yam leaves look like spinach but without the iron-y taste. i guess it's in season now.

we also had clams, crab, sweet and sour spare ribs, and e-noodles... all for a great price. and of course there were plenty of leftovers afterwards!

so although we come here too many times for our own good and are usually served pretty standard fare, it's nice to know that they can whip up a spectacular meal every so often.

***
fyi, my company often orders huge pans of food from here for lunch... they're really good about pulling things together for us and even delivering (ymmv... it may be that we're "regulars" again). around thanksgiving time, they also sell roast-duck style roast turkey... pretty good! also one of the few places in chinatown that has roast goose.
author: Andrey C.

description:
The best kept secret in Chinatown at 3pm they put out several dishes at $2.50 each.  Succulent duck, wings, fried rice, noodles, stir fry veggies, fish.  One dish is enough to be full but I usually get two dishes like the soy sauce duck wings and vegetables.  Eat half of each and take home the rest.  It is a dive place but if you are looking for lunch under $5 try it out.  Greasy yes, noisy yes, not intimate or private yes, decent food yes.  
I love the chicken chow mien they go heavy on the bean sprouts.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
A group of us were looking for some Chinese food and thinking that since we're in China Town we should surely get great Chinese food wherever we went. We saw the good review in the front of the restaurant and was interested in the Peking Duck because the review claimed that it was the best in the city. 

Well the review was badly mistaken, unfortunately. The duck was salty and the skin was not crispy. Everything we ordered was too salty including the fried tofu. To boot, the service was horrible. There were probably only three tables occupied and yet we waited and waited for service. 

The only good thing I have to say is that it was cheap and there was fresh cut watermelon in the end. But that's it. 

Save your money and go somewhere else.
author: Lena N.

description: Two words ... ROAST PORK ... heaven!  The meat is tender and amazing, the skin is crisp like a potato chip, but so much better.  We always get the same thing, Roast Pork, Rice Porridge and Potstickers, so good.  Service here is dicey at best, but who cares when the pork is perfection!
author: Troy C.

description:
