Second visit here and last.

I ordered off of their 3 item menu for $16 thinking it's a good bargain.  I found out why...the food was spoiled.  Salt & Pepper shrimp was ok, except for the 3 or 4 in there that were rotten.  It was absolutely disgusting.  Thanks for ruining my day...I was nauseous for the next 24 hours, but at least I didn't throw up.
author: Matt V.

description: Unbelievable how some of the staff are useless. We waited 30 min for our spare ribs and we asked three times to check on it. One of the servers just walked and came back to sit on his assigned chair. That's his job. Sit there. Then after we paid that useless derp had the nerve to insist we pay more tip. Just about blew steam from my ears.
author: gemste g.

description:
My wife and I took a time out for a day in Chinatown in San Francisco.  As always,
whenever we are in Chinatown, we make a point of having lunch at Yee's Restaurant.  It is not a tourist restaurant, but a local eatery. The atmosphere is
typical of a local restaurant and not at all fancy. The food is what constantly draws us
to this delicious restaurant. The portions are large, the service is good, and the prices are very friendly. The set menu for a three course lunch is under $7.00.
We always order a big bowl of their wonton, noodle, and pork soup and that is
under $7.00 (that is in itself a meal for two). The last trip there, we had the soup,
a  ala carte dish of sweet and sour pork, and a bowl of rice. We had enough
left over for a doggie bag. The price of this banquet was under $15.00. This
included the tea (which comes with the meal) and tax. The tip was extra.
I can't say enough good about this place, except go and enjoy -- I think
you would like it !!!
author: Joseph Y.

description:
Chinese BBQ finger licking good. Try the roast pork, or 3 items for $15. I have never left this place hungry... neither will you.  Best Chinese BBQ I have found in Chinatown. Its a kitchen/cafe so dont expect extravagent decor. Cha siu anyone?

The way I guage a chinese restaurant is by the number of patrons, and how many of the patrons are actually chinese... this place gets an A+. Place is packed with locals during lunch... 


Dont expect the waiter to come to you when you need something. Holler at em and wave em down chinese style. =)
author: Jay P.

description: Come here for good size portions, value for the $, and free soup of the day if you ask nice.  Favorite thing to get here is the duck!
author: Marcus L.

description:
Went to Yee's twice last week while on business in SF.  This place is cheap - especially with their 3 entrees for $15.99 deal though with a catch that I will go into later.

First visit came after a whole day of sightseeing throughout the SF area.  Lots of walking from Nob Hill to Fisherman's Wharf, Ghiradelli Square, Pier 39, North Beach, and all over Chinatown.  Finally decided on Yee's as we wanted to dine at a "hole-in-the-wall" place full of locals.  Placed two take-out orders of their roast duck + roast pork over rice combos ($7.50 with tax each as of 6/19).  Unfortunately, they were out of roast pork so substituted with bbq pork (i.e. the red pork).  The pork was good, no complaints there.  Although the duck was tasty and cooked well, they were on the extremely small/not meaty side.  One thing we really liked about the take out order was that they actually included bok choy with the rice!  The veggie made the takeout order into a more complete meal, i.e. meats, rice, and veggie.  The sauce that was poured over the rice was quite good as well, just wished the duck was meatier.

Second visit was a sit-down dinner.  Went for the 3 entrees for $15.99 deal plus a couple of additional dishes.  Before I go into that, we were pleasantly surprised that we were given a free bowl of artichoke soup/broth.  It was a very simple soup with a couple of pieces of artichokes, but good.  As for the dinner, we got 1) Deep Fried Flounder with sauce 2) Salt & Pepper Shrimp 3) Seafood Tofu Clay Pot  4) Kong Xin Cai 5) Whole Roast Duck.  The last two items were not from the $15.99 deal.  First, the fish was quite small while the salt/pepper shrimp was overcooked as they came out soaking in oil.  The seafood tofu claypot, though good, was NOT a claypot.  It was a mere mini metal wok.  The most disappointing was the duck.  For a whole duck, it was really devoid of meats.  It actually looked like half a duck - for $7/duck I guess that is to be expected.

As with most "hole-in-the-wall" restaurants in Chinatown, there was only one bathroom per sex and it was essentially a closet.  To get to it, you must walk through the dish-washing part of the kitchen with dirty/used plate/bowls stacked everywhere.  I got so tired of waiting to wash my hands in the bathroom that I just washed them over the industrial sized kitchen sink.  

Overall, the dinner was somewhat disappointing, not bad, but also not great.  Came out to about $45.  Decent meal - A-OK.  Bear in mind - cash only.
author: Melvin B.

description:
Shrimp with scrambled egg. Try it.

Went to SF several months ago and wanted to eat Chinatown for sure. This place was filled with locals so you know what that means. Prices were great and there are alot of items on the menu. What it would take  2 chinatown restaurants in Chicago was accomplished here if that makes any sense.
author: Marcus Z.

description:
Yee's restaurant is a solid, unpretentious Cantonese restaurant in the heart of Chinatown where you can get a good, simple meal at an extremely reasonable price.   The restaurant is popular with Chinatown residents, which speaks volumes about the quality.  There is also a Chinese BBQ on the premises, with the usual 
char siu pork, duck, chicken, and cuttlefish gracing the front window.

Sure, you can get sweet-and-sour pork, but during lunchtime, most folks gravitate towards the rice plates; the fish fillet and vegetables over rice seem popular, while I prefer the BBQ pork and duck with rice.  Most rice plates are $7 or less and include a large bowl of soup (the composition of which seems to vary day by day, but seems to include
lotus root and pork neck bones; it's always quite good). You can watch as the BBQ meats are unhooked, chopped, and plated for your table, so the meats are a low-risk path to a good meal.

there is also a $15-for-3-dishes option, where you select from any 3 items from a substantial menu.  I've only tried a few of them (Chinese broccoli, BBQ pork, and braised tofu), but they were all solid and the ingredients were fresh. there are many more items on the menu, and I bet there are several culinary gems hidden within.

all in all, if you're looking for a good, unpretentious meal,  try Yee's.  As with many authentic Chinese restaurants, the menu rewards the open-minded eater.
author: Rob Y.

description:
Still not my favorite little Hong Kong cafe (next to Washington Bakery), but it is definitely up-and-coming on my list.  The real draw to Yee's for me has always been their breakfast jok special.  For the ungodly price of $2.50 (if my memory serves me right), one gets a HUGE bowl of jok with yao ja guai on the side (or cut-up into the jok).  Additionally, one can have anything from shredded pork to thousand-year egg in your jok.  So, for your two-fifty, you tend to get a lot.  As well, Yee's duck is a treat, either to eat there or to take home.
  So, Yee's is yet my favorite little place but, who knows, if I find myself going there more and more, the tides may turn!
author: Scott N.

description: Good chinese food.  Portions were hearty especially for the price.  I got a bowl of noodles for under $5.  It didn't look that big when it came, but man was it PACKED with noodles, meat, preserved vegetables, sprouts.  A little salty for my taste.  But we ordered a plate of duck for the table and it was also a lot of meat for the price.  I'd go back...would not order the pork/preserved veg noodles again tho.
author: Kelly K.

description: I am definitely not impressed with this particular restaurant. Let's just say the service sucks. We wanted to add a particular item to a dish, and no matter how hard we tried, he would not accommodate to our liking. He just kept nodding, NO! NO! NO!.  A bit rude I would say. A lady came out with all kinds of dishes for a special price, like goose feet, chicken wings, and sweet and sour pork, which was all set up on two large tables. I noticed everyone was grabbing something, so I went up to the lady who was preparing the plates what were these particular dishes. And she stared me like I was crazy. I did spoke to her in cantonese, but she seemed disturbed like I have the nerve to ask her about the dish or the prices of each item. Eventually I took a plate home for my dad to eat cause he loves goose feet. The food was pretty good, but the service leaves me totally disturbed. I have never encounter such rudeness in my life. My husband plate had arrived 20 minutes earlier while I sat there watching him eat, before my plate arrives. I enjoyed my dish, and It was pretty tasty, and the prices are pretty reasonable, but I would not ever go back, Next time, I'm in Chinatown, I'm going to search around a bit longer instead of going to the first place I see. That was my mistake.
author: Jenny W.

description:
food here is really cheap, no kidding.  some dishes were $4.75!...  =o

absolutely tasty, most of them hong kong derived, dishes u dont normally find in other chinese restaurants, mmm...

jook was full of flavor, maybe the best i've ever had, mmm...  that 1000-year old egg, coulda been 10,000-year old, so f-ing gooooood.  each slurp of gruel, orgasmic... 

duck was pretty fatty though.  a lot of oil in their food (like i said, hong kong).  interior could use a cleaning.  

some drunk 60-yr old farts across the room were arguing pretty loud.  all the kitchen staff in their aprons swarmed out, and just stood there and observed, like indecisive meerkats, haha...
author: Ethan L.

description: This  one of the oldest business in Chinatown. My wife and family go there often because I live in north beach. it is very average looking restaurant and lunch time gets crowded so get there a few minutes before lunch. they have a large menu and serve everything from 3 dishes for $15.00 to more typical dishes around 5-7dollars. I notice many people order beef dishes apparently regular favorites and roast duck over rice, won ton is (not now) backward and they do have that.  OK the NEGS  no parking don't think about it, orders come out from the kitchens all different time, who every your eating with may have to wait 10 minutes longer while your eating now. noisy and bathroom is 3 out of 10. table of 7people cost us $40.00 without tips.
author: Howard J.

description: I stumbled in here today for some rice porridge to go since I'm sick as hell.  As I was waiting for my order, I noticed two large tables with dishes set out - chicken, chow mein, veggies, tofu mushroom, EVERYTHING!  People were eyeing the dishes, taking what they wanted, and getting it to go.  For $2.50-$3.50 per dish. OMFG. If I wasn't so sick and could eat normal food, I would have totally gotten a few dishes to go because they looked well cooked.  As for the porridge, the ingredients were quality, it wasn't oily and so very cheap at $3.  The staff was also super friendly, seeing that I was pale and near death.  Definitely going to come here again if I make it through the week!
author: Wendy T.

description: My visit here was a nightmare.  I wasn't given a menu - I had to get one myself. I was given tea in an old coffee mug.  The waiter took my order and then ignored me.  The simple noodle dish I ordered took over 20 minutes to come out, although the place wasn't busy by any means.  And lastly, I wasn't given a tab - I had to go to the counter to explain to the lady there what I had ordered so that I could pay and get the hell out of there...
author: Nathan W.

description: The chicken is wicked good.  It's cheap.  The quality is definitely better than what you pay for.  For $17.00 including tip I had enough food to feed me for two more meals.
author: Po L.

description:
Good basic Chinese Food without the frills. Fresh food, high turnover of dishes seem to show with the freshness of the food. 
Inexpensive and a great smattering of dishes to choose from

Definitely worth returning to
author: C Y.

description:
I was always wondering why this place has so many people always.  Either it must be 1) very cheap for their food or 2) very good for the price...  It was 1) this case.  

Ah by the way I saw the chef cutting ducks picking his nose without even thinking whether he should hide it.  Wonderful, that's Chinatown...

Pricing is incredible that you will want to act you didn't see the chef picking his nose and going back to cut more ducks and pigs...
author: T T.

description:
Oh my freaking god this place smells something awful! I don't know how people sit there like the stench is okay!

I peeked in and saw a good number of people. So maybe the place is good, since they've got customers. So I took about 7 steps in and then noticed the smell. I think maybe I went too far into the restaurant, it'd be weird if I turned and left. I thought maybe after a few minutes my nose will get used to the smell. So I sat down at a small table a ways in. My god, it was like day old cuttlefish odor in the air.

I got combo crispy noodle. The plate was huge for $6/$7. Lots of stuff. But OHH the humanity!! That horrible smell came from my food too! It's everywhere. The plate looked decent (though I don't care too much for the gooey light brown sauce, yeck). Every single bite was filled with the odor that just made me sick. I managed to take several bites and took the rest to go (thinking I may be able to salvage some of the meats then toss the now-soggy noodles). There was a lot left over. Normally, I would have half left over of such a large plate. 

I ended up tossing the food. Realistically, there's no way I'll be touching it again. The thought of the food and restaurant made me queasy.

Of course I felt bad for tossing the food. But man, I can't stand to think of the SMELL!

Never going back there again. Cheap or not.

Side note: when you enter, there's a small station with roasted fowls and whatever else. There was a container of raw dried  duck leg and thighs just sitting next to the counter. Pretty gross. I'm all good with roast duck, chicken, whatever. But seeing the dried raw meat was just EWWW!
author: Hmmm O K.

description:
I've never had a bad meal here but be forewarned that the service is sometimes non-existent.

They also have platters of food for take out spread out on a large table by 3:00 pm; you pick the dish you want, take it to the cashier, she boxes it,  takes your $3.00 (?), and off you go.
author: John C.

description: Not bad. Not the best Chinese in the city, but definitely not the worst. Cheap, good and filling. If you want better Chinese, pay more at the upscale places like Chef Jias or R&G  or venture into the more authentic places that tend to cater to the Chinese immigrants who live up in the buildings overlooking Chinatown.
author: Hal C.

description:
Lots of average tasting food for about $5.  I had the steam chicken with ginger sauce and comes with house soup on the side.  It wasn't so cheap since they had waiters, and I ended up spending $8 for an average, large portioned dish with tip.  I drank the free tea.

The plates of food they put out on the tables for people to pick up is to move their inventory so the next day has fresh food.  It's priced low, for many folks who want to take it to go.

I would come here again if i wanted a cheap, decent tasting eat.
author: Kevin T.

description:
check out the goose over rice "economy plate."  cheap and filling, less than usd $6 and try with the plum (light yellow in color) dipping sauce.  it is sweet and sour.  if you want the most "bang" for your buck, go in after 1500hrs for the "happy hour."  taste is not that great, but quantity makes up for it.  less then usd $2.50 for a huge plate of bbq meats (pork and chicken).  best, bt.

p.s. location is near the top of grant street (before chinatown turns into little italy) on the same side as "yoogo gelato" keep walking down sidewalk for less than 5 mins)
author: beijing t.

description: Cheep and Yammy. I strongly reccomend roast duck. Combo menu for 3 dishes is very reasonable. I am a big fan of this noisy restaurant!
author: Takako O.

description:
This is a recent discovery & now one of my favorite inexpensive, casual Chinese restaurants in Chinatown with really good food. 

Went there for lunch the other day & was underwhelmed by the beef w/tomato rice dish -- not their specialty, but I don't usually order that dish at most restaurants anyway so it was a crap shoot. My dining partner was happy with his Singapore Mai Fun & he's pretty hard to please.

As for dinner, this place rocks. They have a special menu where you can order 3 dishes for about $20 & the portions are generous! We ordered the shrimp w/walnuts, chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, and the chicken w/ginger & onions -- OMG that was good. We ordered a 4th dish on the side since there were four of us -- curry beef -- and that turned out to be nothing special.

I will definitely be eating here again in the future. Good food & inexpensive. Otherwise clean & good service. Nothing fancy in terms of ambience but you're coming for the good food & cheap eats!
author: D L.

description:
this is one of my favorite chinatown restaurants! the service was very fast and the food was EXCELLENT!!!

I ordered a plate of SNAILS, POT of RICE, GREENS, hot tea

the snails were very good, lots of sauce and you have to use a tooth pick to get the meat out after sucking out the delicious sauce
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: I stumbled upon this restaurant on Grant, close to Broadway. In terms of price, it's almost unmatched by any Chinese restaurants I ever visited. For $15.99, you can get 3 dishes. The selection is quite large. The portion of each dish is simply amazing. I ordered crispy chicken. I was expecting the usual  1/2 chicken. But they served up the whole chicken. Deep fried flat fish, walnut prawn, pan fried noodles are all amazingly big portioned. I have seen other tables that orders broccoli beef, portion is almost 50% more than other restaurants. I have been there twice, will definitely go back again next time I am in Chinatown. It's not a place for atmosphere. It's loud and a bit dirty too. Go there for the food only, after a long day of shopping in San Francisco.
author: Eric C.

description: one of the best noodle houses in SF Chinatown. i had the wonton egg noodle soup with fish ball. vivid memories of Hong Kong da pai don's came back.  the noodles were crunchy, the wonton's are so fresh, and the fish ball very savory. parking is a pain, of course. we also ordered the Chinese donut with fish fillet rice porridge.  we kept on eating while the porridge was too hot.  i think my tongue was also cooked.
author: Agent X.

description: pretty good authentic chinese food
author: Cindy L.

description: Mainly a place where Chinese locals come for their Chinese food.  Once in a while you'll see a tourist venture in and order a small sampler of their roast or bbq pork, but that is about it.  I read some comments about Yee's food being greasy but I'm going to have to disagree.  They do use oil like most Chinese restaurants, but it's not over the top.  I love their wonton soup for $3.75 ... it's great tasting and there is plenty of wontons.  Can't find wonton soup in the OC for $3.75.
author: Jo M.

description: This restaurant is a great choice if you find yourself in Chinatown and want to have an economical family dinner that is truly representative of fresh Cantonese/Hong Kong food. We had a dinner party of six, composed of some pretty picky Chinese relatives, and we were amazed that we could get 6 generous-sized, well-prepared dishes and a soup for $32 (we ordered from the "3 dishes for $15.99" menu).  We couldn't finish it all. There was even watermelon for desert, for a nice touch. As mentioned elsewhere, the decor is nothing special, but that, to me, adds to its authenticity - this is not a restaurant that has sold its soul to the tourists.
author: Oh G.

description: the family always eats here for chinese new year.  good portions.  really, really good crispy pork and bbq pork (cha-siu), and standard chicken.  never have the goose available - eva c. says below to reserve in advance - we'll have to try that next year.  have eaten the standard chinese food here too, and it's good and plentiful.  not touristy either - more chinese than euro faces is always a good sign in chinatown!
author: Chris D.

description: It's too easy for people to criticize Yee's.  I love the faces and comments from the tourists as they photograph the window display.  Sure, a neon orange octopus is something to write home about.  But you have to go in and order take out a few times to experience the place.  The first time, you'll wait patiently as everyone cuts in front of you.  You'll initially be offended but the feeling of victory from stopping your first regular from cutting in line is priceless.  It has nothing to do with race.  It's all about who wants their bbq pork first.  At least that's what I usually order along with fried chicken wings or peking duck.  I'm too chicken to experiment there.  You'll feel bad about the prices because something must have been lost in translation.  $5 for all that food?  Oh, trying to order a small order of rice is fun too.  I ended up with a family size order one time.  Now I think they just know me and pretend to understand me.
author: Ivan N.

description: Good ol' greasy Chinese food done authentic. Don't expect a posh/sterile environment. Just good food at a reasonable price. I recommend the roasted pig and duck.
author: Daniel L.

description: well, i'd give it three and a half if i could, but... so my friend took me here for dinner last night and we did the three dishes for $15.99 deal. can i just say that the fried flounder was amazing (especially for that price) and a good size! the salt and pepper spare ribs were yummy, but my friend unfortunately got the piece slathered in MSG - you could actually see it all over the meat - so she thought it was too salty. we also got beef and broccoli - very fresh veggies cooked just right. the free soup was good as well - i think it was some kind of melon soup. service friendly and efficient, but everyone in the service industry seems to love my friend wherever we go, so that was no surprise. other notes: 1) it helps if you speak cantonese or go with someone who does - this will greatly enhance your dining experience. 2) the place was kind of dirty, so you need to block it out of your mind. my friend and i agree that if you don't get sick afterwards, then it's ok, given the prices and quantity of food. and i'm a virgo, so you know i know what i'm talking about.
author: Dorothy W.
